I am satisfied about Sichuan Cuisine here. Only one thing is that I am not quite into (Although I understand why they do that) is that they passed my receipt a bit too soon.

Overall, I have no problem since I just had a road trip and stopped by Pittsburgh.

Sushi is unbelievable. I am from Bethel but have lived in Atlanta for a while now. I've had plenty of wonderful sushi from all over the country but this is no joke THE BEST. Sounds weird to say but we loved it. Huge portions of fresh fish that melts in your mouth like butter. The Royal Boat is THE best! I've had sushi from fancy places in ATL...LA....and so on...this has been the best!

I LOVE this place! It's a fun place to bring people from out of town. The hot pot serving is huge and there is always leftovers to take home. I have to say that this is a place where you will find yourself trying something new to you. The variety of veggies and meat that go into the pot is pretty awesome. I'm so excited that it's fall and it's becoming soup weather again! Get creative with your pot and be ok to laughing at yourself. This is a messy meal sometimes and a bib may come in handy! A great way to meet others sitting next to you too!

This place is great for authentic Chinese and not like anything else I have experienced in Pittsburgh.  I noticed many of the average reviews focused on "Americanized" Chinese food which is average everywhere.  They have some nonstandard offerings like tripe, pork belly and squid and The Szechuan dishes are hot, authentic and fantastic.  Be adventurous and you won't be disappointed.

A good friend of my husband's and mine said that this restaurant was the "best Chinese restaurant in Pittsburgh," so the three of us decided to give it a try today. From driving by the outside, the restaurant doesn't look like much. The inside was a bit nicer than I had expected, and I was impressed by the service. All of our food came out very quickly, and we received water refill offers at least 5 times.

We split a Crab Rangoon appetizer, and it was absolutely delicious. I will definitely be craving those cream cheese filled dumplings some time very soon. For my entree, I ordered the Sweet and Sour Chicken combination platter. It was very tasty and a very good quality. For the food we received - and the Squirrel Hill location - I thought the prices were very reasonable. I hope to return again very soon!
A wonderful spot for lunch. The selection is good. The place is very clean and the staff is on top of it!  The are just behind Crackwhore Barrel.

This was our first experience at a hot pot restaurant. The waiter was extremely helpful and patient with us!  We  really ebuoyed the meal and can't wait to do it again.   I had the crab legs. I made a mess with them, bit they were delicious.   My daughter had the seafood  combo. It had octopus. Squid, fish, shrimp, etc. She said all the fish were good, my husband did the pork combo.  Everyone enjoyed their food. I highly recommend this place!

The hubster and I finally made it in here to make a comparison between China Star and How Lee. The service here is incredibly friendly and accommodating, and they clearly are used to dealing with English speaking clientele.

Surprisingly, the servers were Cantonese. I liked this because I could speak with them without much trouble, but this is where I thought the food might have been a bit lacking. We got our usual, which is fish fillets in spicy broth and pea shoots. The pea shoots were a bit on the tough side (might just have been due to what was available) and we were able to get the fish fillets a bit more mild than usual. Maybe getting it mild was where we went wrong - Sad to say, but the fish fillets at China Star are significantly better. Allow me to explain just a bit - the fish fillet dish at How Lee's was a bit ... cantonesed (i.e., they had thickened up the soup base with corn starch, which is a pretty typical cantonese thing to do). Also, the fish fillets were a bit on the doughy side, which I think probably had everything to do with the fish they used. 

Anyway, this is not a crazy indictment - it was still really good Chinese food, especially by Pittsburgh standards. I especially liked it because I could actually speak with the servers. But if you're looking for really authentic Szechuan food, I'd recommend China Star over this.

Excellent food, something to suit a lot of taste buds!
Been here multiple times. Went for the classics, orange chicken and Kung Pao chicken as well as some of their signature dishes, loved them all!
Very conveniently located and great prices for the food. The portion is good and I generally end up taking some back for later

This super popular spot has been on my list of places to visit for a while, and I'm glad I finally decided to try it out! This place is called "Mini hot pot" for a reason, since you each get your own personal hot pot, which is pretty different from the traditional large hot pot in the middle that everyone shares. Because of this, the price is on the higher side (~$18 with tax and tip for a beef plate), but you do get quite a lot of food!

The meat itself was delicious, and the mixed vegetables were also great. The service was fairly fast and they have a sauce bar where you can create your own dipping sauce which was pretty neat. They also have unlimited noodles which was awesome! 

This place is certainly a more Americanized version of the hot pot I'm used to, but I still really enjoyed the food. I could imagine that this place would really hit the spot on a cold Wisconsin winter day. I'll definitely be back!

We love this restaurant!  The food is delicious and the employees are very, very nice!  Pan and everyone there are wonderful.  So very gracious and sincere!  Their restaurant is warm and cozy with warming pads right on the tables. Very unique and efficient. And we're excited because they are now in a great location close to us, on S Park St, right next to Pick 'n Save.
Try Double 10!  You'll love it, too.

Been wanting to try How Lee for a while now. It is one of the few places I haven't been to in Sq. Hill. Food was pretty good and the service was good. Some things on the menu were cheap while others were more expensive. It was good middle of the road Chinese food. 3.5-4.0

I just came back from eating at the Rice Inn with my parents.  

In terms of appearance, the restaurant is clean and roomy, which made me feel quite comfortable.  The owners definitely paid attention to the small details from the cute tea cups to the nice placemats.

As for the food, everything that we ordered was delicious.  I really enjoyed the Shanghai bok choy that was lightly sauteed.  As the previous Yelper said, the food was not too greasy.  Also, the flavors fit the taste of my parents, who are originally from Hong Kong and Canton, China.

I would recommend this place to friends and family.  Unfortunately, I live in Boston, so I cannot come as often as I would like.  However, when I do come back, this will be a place I will request to go out for dinner, whenever I come home to visit my parents.

I hope this place does well, as it just opened up.  The owners are very nice people!  

Give this place a try!

One of my favorite take out places. I'm sure dining in is better in some ways, as you get to dip your own food. But for delivery they cook the stuff for you (lightly steamed) and you can dip it at home though it's not as hot. 

Madison is a place where the food often looks better than it tastes - looking at you Sujeo and DLUX - like it's made for Instagram rather than ingestion. Double 10 is a welcome exception. The food is delicious, filling, the Szechuan is actually spicy and they pack your delivery in a way that makes sense, including extras like custom mixed dipping sauce with fresh garlic and cilantro - since you can't go to the condiment station yourself. 

This place is a go-to for those cold Wisconsin days.

Never used to come here before the renovations but had heard that this place had good things going for it now.  Came here with my boyfriend and we are hooked; nearly everything we've had from here has been excellent.

There's the standard American Chinese menu that has all of your standard offerings (have had the General Tso tofu at the restaurant which was surprisingly fantastic) but turn to the back of the menu where you'll find the authentic Sichuan menu that has enough spicy food on it to burn a hole in your tongue.

My boyfriend loves authentic Asian cuisine so he always gets something from the authentic menu (e.g. the spicy prawns, chongqing chicken) while I get something far less adventurous (chow fun, hor fun, etc.) to give my poor tongue a break from the spice after I steal a few bites of his meals.  

Love this place for both eat-in and take-out and highly recommend this place as one of the best Chinese restaurants in Pittsburgh.

I've never done the little hot pot thing but mostly order take out. 

Honestly they have pretty great food overall and awesome service. 

The first time I went - I asked for chopsticks and pointed towards the decorative chopsticks on the counter. The woman behind the counter was like - uh those are for decoration but here you can have a pair anyway as long as you promise to be a repeat customer. 

Good thing this place is awesome or I wouldn't be able to keep that promise lmao.

I honestly love this restaurant. I come here probably once every two weeks or whenever on a rainy day. Service is great. Family owned restaurant. One of the owners is a woman that always works in the front. She's awesome! Probably the sweetest lady ever even though she doesn't speak much English. The food you get is at a great price & good quality. You also get an unlimited noodle & condiment bar. Whereas many other hot pot places I've been to in the past, you have to pay extra for noodles & sauces. This place is a hidden gem.

Definitely as good as it gets ! Huge portions. Went in for lunch on the weekend and it was $13-$15/person which is an excellent deal considering how much food you get. We had enough leftovers for two more meals. Hosts were very friendly and were patient in explaining how hot pot works. They checked on everyone a few times and made sure everyone was enjoying their meal. It is also all you can eat ! Flavors were fantastic ! Must try and well worth the money.

Omgosh!!!! The food was not to live for but the sushi was!!!!! The dishes were not clean and the waiter was too old to be waiting tables. The greeters clothes were dirty but I like how involved she was with making sure we got something delicious. We did...the sushi.

We've been coming here for a while. I always order the Chongqing Chicken. Tonight I enjoyed it the most I ever have. (I am wondering  if they changed the kitchen staff, as the dish has gone from really good to great). Last time, there wasn't any salt on the chicken, this time it was seasoned and cooked perfectly.  
My husband had the beef and green beans and the meat was very tender.  We both enjoyed our meal as usual, but tonight it was over the top.

This place is amazing! We went here spontaneously trying to find a spot and we definitely hit gold! The staff was super accommodating and helped us out knowing we were first timers. Clean and quaint and packed full of people this place is a go to if you're looking for a filling meal. Both broths we had were great and the suggested house sauce at the noodle bar was amazing! Will go back again and again! Also loved the unique write on your menu quirk!

This place used to be SO GOOD.  Sadly over the past few years its really not stood up to previous visits.  The sushi was always fresh, but no longer.  The dinners were seasoned well and presented nicely, but recently they have been over salted and kind of sloppy.  Not sure what happened, but its been months since we've visited and I dont think we will return.

WORST CUSTOMER SERVICE EVER!  I ordered my usual, Orange chicken with Fried rice instead of white rice (Up charged $2 for that) and I always order an extra carton of the rice so I have it with my leftovers.  Normally it's $2 dollars extra for that as well.  I also asked for the real hot mustard not packets.  I noticed when I got there to pick up my food that HOW LEE had called my cellphone 2 times so I went inside to pick up my food.  The lady (owner) said she tried to call me and that my "extra fried rice" needed to come with chicken, pork, or shrimp.  I said, does the fried rice that comes with my dinner have chicken, pork, or shrimp in it?  She said no.  SO I asked well can I please have a carton of the rice that comes with my dinner like I normally get?  She said no.  SO I have to pay $10 extra dollars to get extra rice?  She said yes.  COME ON!  She was so focused on beating me for extra money that they got my order all wrong!  I did not get orange chicken, I got general Tso's and I asked for the REAL hot mustard and I got packets.  The food is overpriced as it is and YES it's delicious but not worth $30 for one meal...  How Lee lost a regular customer yesterday for sure!  I will drive the extra mile and go to The Sesame Inn in the city from now on.  The food is way better and they do not give packet mustard.  They have homemade mustard that is do die for!  TEN thumbs down for How Lee and the way they treated me yesterday.  No food is good enough to be treated like that!  EVER!
Spent 50 dollars on food here and only got half of what I paid for. I called to complain and they wouldn't give me what I was missing from my order

A family favorite that we go to or order from almost every month.  My favorite is the garlic eggplant or the tofu and eggplant.  The kids love the lo mein and chicken w baby corn and garlic sauce with a side of edamame.  Highly recommend!
Update: It was so tasty I went back for dinner.  Same good taste.  Went back hotel and felt bloated.  Starting to have diahrea next morning till late afternoon.  Won't go back.

Really nice people. 

Now the food. I liked what I ate but I didn't know if I was in a Thai, Chinese, Japanese or whatever restaurant. Totes confused.

Also, it's BOYB so there's a cork fee. That's fine but there were 6 of us. We had three bottles (one was just a beer), and we got THREE CORK fees. Ugh. You should charge one cork fee per table!

I did like the General Tso's but my friend's didn't like the Pad Thai at all.

Went here tonight to try again. Last time I went was about 6 months ago. Wasn't keen on going back since last time I had noticed service and food quality had declined. Tonight we walked in noticed the unclean restaurant including an employee sitting in a booth with his shoes off and feet up in the booth. The place was also almost empty which surprised me in how long it took for hostess to recognize our presence in seating us. Needless to say I will not be going back. Got a much better dinner elsewhere tonight.

Picked up from Rice Inn tonight for the first time. Whole family loved it! General Tso was best I've had in Pittsburgh. Shrimp with lo mein had actual shrimp in it. The rainbow and California rolls were packed with ice and came with a little dish for me to put soy sauce in. This will be our place to get Chinese/Japanese take out from now on, can't wait to take my friend from out of town for Sushi lunch.

Let me start by saying I was surprised to know that this restaurant even existed, like I'm such a huge fan of Asian cuisine to where I was shocked I hadn't heard of this place especially seeings as how close it is to me. We took a visit down to Rice Inn and upon entering we were greeted by a friendly Asian waitress (no surprise there) and she sat us down and almost immediately asked what we wanted to drink. Now it seems they have a thing with tea seeings as how she brought a cast iron pot over and started by pouring us mugs of it (upon request of course as she asked if we would like tea) and I will say it was quite good. Our first thoughts were on the decor, it was quite dated but oddly nostalgic. The reason for this come to find was that the place was built inside of an old Pizza Hut that closed down about 5-6 years ago. As for our waitress she spoke English but her accent at times was a bit hard to grasp and did happen to cause a misunderstanding about our leftovers being boxed. But nonetheless she was very attentive and respondent. After placing our orders the food was shockingly on the table in under 3 minutes! Albeit the place was a ghost town as there were about 4-5 other customers in the entire building, but still fast nonetheless. My sushi was pretty good although I didn't fancy the chewy salmon in my salmon roll. The California roll was about as good as a California roll can be so that was nice. The fantastic roll was oddly warm on top but I found I kind of liked it as it added some depth to the mouthfeel. And the ginger salad on the side did not look very visually appealing but tasted decent, I would go for the wanton soup as a side if I ever went again though (I most likely will). And as for the person I was with they got the sesame chicken with white rice and wanton soup as a side. They said that the rice was perfect but the chicken had an odd texture and it was much too sweat. They gave the wanton soup rave reviews however. I also ordered a takeout of orange chicken with white rice for one of my family members and they even said it was getting hard to eat it near the end seeings as how sweet it was, they compared it to panda expresses orange chicken saying it's about 5x sweeter and not nearly as good. I would recommend sticking to Japanese food if you plan a visit. Overall my experience was a good one and I recommend it to any hardcore fish fans in the area. 3/5

Rice Inn is a perfect example of why we should not judge a book by its cover. I utterly was surprised when I walked through the door. 

Regarding the building, they did a wonderful job transforming this old pizza hut. All the tables have been refinished with stone design on top. They have a floor plan consisting of tables and booths, which are all spaced out nicely so that you are not on top of the person next to you. They also have actual place settings on each table which is a nice touch. 

Now on to the food. Simply put,it was delicious. I'm very picky when it comes to sushi, but this truly hit the spot. My favorite is salmon nigiri, and there's did not disappoint. 

The service was wonderful. Our server was attentive and pleasant without being overbearing, and the food was at our table quicker than I had imagined. 

I cannot wait to come back and explore the rest of their menu!

Sooooo we order General Tso Chicken with white rice and a Thai iced tea and we get food with hair in it. Their solution: an offer of free rice. FUCK THAT! Yet another example of why i dont eat this kind of shit in the first place. Eat here at your own risk

Decent food - affordable and generous size. If you pay in cash you can get 10% off.

Meat isn't the greatest (a lot of fatty part) but for the price it's worth it. Went in on a Friday night and there were plenty of seats to choose from. I would go if I am in the campus area again.

So..... I actually never got anything.   I was attempting to order from an online site to the one on the west side.   I thought it was their individual webpage, but I was mistaken.  I paid online.  When I went to the west side location, we discovered the mistake.   So I called and tried to see if I could transfer the order.   The lady got very rude and said I needed to call the webpage and refused to help me.   I discovered that<U+200B> the webpage doesn't have a phone number.   So, I ordered at the correct one and figured that I would sort out the webpage later.   5 minutes later, the same lady called back to tell me to pick up my food.   I explained very short that I just called and I am not transversing the city to pick it up.   At this point the lady got nasty and said well you don't care that the food comes out of our pocket.   I PAID ONLINE!!!!!!    So, it is me that is out of the money.   I explained that and she went yeah, yeah, yeah.    

Point is....  There is no purpose of the rudeness of that lady.   And a little customer service goes a long way.   I live near this location, but will never try it...

Came here w my brother to grab lunch on a weekday - pretty empty and very easy to find seats. Service was quick after we ordered at the counter, and we entertained ourselves with the asian game show playing from TV on the wall. I got the spicy fish fillet special noodle, and my brother got the shredded pork with pickled mustard green. We also ordered pork and Napa cabbage dumplings to share. So much food! 
Taste of both broths was light, but a little oily on the shredded pork soup. The dumplings packed amazing flavor. Would definitely tag this as a go-to place for hot noodle soup cravings.

We first went to Chan an, but after standing for a long time, we turned around and went to Panda (both in the same plaza). We had never tried either as we are new to the area. We were not disappointed. The egg rolls are some of the best I've ever had. The crab Rangoon with sweet and sour dipping sauce was spot on. My boyfriend really enjoyed the fried rice, and I liked the white rice. His general sos was moist and sweet, but not spicy at all. My sesame chicken was pretty good and the meat was moist as well. Then as an added bonus, the manager handed us a free 2 liter to go as well. We will definitely be back to try more entrees.

I cannot believe I didn't review this restaurant earlier. This has been my fav chinese spot for years! Even before they remodeled. I usually get the vegetable hor fun or the general tsos tofu. It is nothing super fancy, it is not a big restaurant, but it is just really spot on chinese food, every time. They have a very interesting szechuan menu too in the back of their "americanized" menu. The servers are very friendly and so are the owners, who are always up front handling the take outs and phone calls. 

Tonight I stopped in and ordered my usual general tsos tofu. It has a sweet and spicy sauce and the tofu is crispy on the outside and chewy on the inside. I often add extra broccoli. If you are in the squirrel hill area, go to this gem!

I always enjoy my food from Rice Inn. I'm only writing this review in hopes that someone sees my complaint and fixes it. Last night I ordered a couple of entrees and a $14 sushi roll. When I got home I realized the sushi was in the same bag on top of all of the hot food. The sushi was very warm and didn't taste good because of that. I tried refrigerating it for a bit but it made it a little too hard. Unfortunately it was just 14 bucks down the drain. Hopefully someone at Rice Inn will see this and make sure sushi orders are bagged separately and come with ice!

Ordered orange chicken and fried rice.  I don't know why this place always tries to pass off fried rice as white rice with soy sauce? Is it because it's just faster and lazier to take white rice and pour sauce in it? Not good. I didn't like the orange chicken either. We also got the Szechuan chicken with fried rice. My husband is is wasn't good. Not slice and you already know about the fried rice. The only thing good was the vegetable egg rolls and fortune cookies. In past orders, I do like their hunan beef.

Have been curious about this place for a while and finally had the chance to stop in. I was immediately greeted by the hostess/waitress who asked if I had ever been in before. She guided me through the menu options. It wasn't hard to decide to go with a hot pot, seafood and extra spicy. She set up my table and took me to the "noodle"/sauce bar. She showed me how to mix up a typical sauce, making it extra spicy for me. She advised me as to cooking times for the various items on my plates. Everything was fantastic and exceptional service! I highly recommend this place!

Newbie to Hot Pot (so much that I had to look it up on youtube!), but saw the fun reviews from fellow yelpers and thought "I need to try this!" I admit I was scared about the "cooking my own RAW chicken meat" (from one plate, touching everything under it, to the reusable soup, one set of chopsticks that touch raw, soup, and cooked) without any friend there to "hold my hand" - I mean I was FREAKED. But everything went well and I had alot of fun.

So for those of you new like me and without a guide:
1) You sit down and pick soup base + meat choice. ASK to sample the broth before choosing.
2) Your soup base is just for cooking - you're NOT going to pour it back over noodles. 
3) As your base warms to boil, go to the condiment buffet and pick up stuff you would like. I had done some youtubing beforehand, so I used a couple of sauce recommendations from there, but really my favorite was the (only) one the restaurant provided (on the glass of the buffet server). Another one I liked is a "traditional" sauce from some province in China: 1 ladle sesame paste + 1 spoon chive paste.
4) While your base is still warming up, or if you took forever to get your "extras" like me, I added scallions, chili oil, cilantro, and garlic. I wanted to "spruce up" the mushroom base soup. It smelled fine, but I do like a "little" heat (like a level 1 on 5). The yelpers scared me on the heat levels from the "Kimchi" and "Szechuan." Someone mentioned asking for a level one, but this was not an option during my visit. My extras on the "mushroom" broth ended up perfect for me. In fact, as a salt loving American, once the broth condensed a little, it was a knock out!
5) Next, add hard veggies. Now there are NO signs to tell you how long to cook anything. I think I let the broccoli cook for 4-5 min - a tad too mushy. The corn was 20 min - ok. The fish and shrimp balls, fried tofu, soft tofu were 1-2 min - they were fine for me and surprisingly tasted better than the chicken. "Fish ball" sounds "fishy" to me, but they were flavorful and a nice chew (kinda like a softer matzo ball). I never used the soft veggies (leaves).
6) Then, the meat. The server mentioned 30 secs - 1 min for the raw chicken slice. It does change color enough to notice if it's still raw, but I made sure to kill it a little extra. Chopsticks: to kill the chicken bacteria, redip the chopsticks in the boiling soup. In fact, I LEFT them in the boiling soup for the 1 min that my chicken was cooking. The fake crab and some weird white shaved "fish" (?) slices took about 20 sec to cook. I was NOT coordinated enough to time all this perfectly the first time out, so I just cooked one or two things at once then ate as they were coming out (Redip those chopsticks FREQUENTLY).
7) Once I got all my goodies cooked and eaten. I went for the ramen noodles (2 min), adding fresh chili oil, scallions, garlic, and cilantro for the cooking and post-cooking. By this point the corn was ready, and I added it to the noodles. Great noodles! 4/5

Cons:
Contrary to other reviews, on my visit, there were no eggs and no fresh fruit.
I wish they had an extra list of how to make sauces - since we did go to cook our food, I like having recipes!
I would also like something to tell me how long to cook the items. Again the recipe thing.
Lunch price has increased (from yelp reviews) - $12/person + $1.50 for a can of coke.

Overall:
Fun and tasty. But it's only as good as YOUR cooking that day. 3.5/5

Ps. for those of you like me, I did NOT get food poisoning!

We had to go into Bethel Park last night and came here to yelp to find a restaurant. When we saw Rice Inn and saw it had not only sushi and sashimi, but it also serves traditional chinese  and Thai foods also.. After reading some of the reviews, we knew we had to try it and the reviews were right on the money.
We ordered 3 different rolls,  the Philadelphia roll, the Chicken Tempura Roll and the Sweet Potato Tempura roll, along with a side order of Chicken Egg rolls..We were quite surprised at how quickly the egg rollscame out and they were actually good sized and very tasty. While still eating them, our rolls came out and almost looked too nice to eat. I say almost, because we love sushi and couldn't wait to try it, besed on all the reviews.
We were NOT disappointed one iota, as these rolls were fresh and their tastes were quite different and distinct. We ended up taking home almost half the pieces of the rolls, as this meal was rather filling for the 2 of us.
As we Now have to go to Bethel Park regularly, we WILL be back and soon, as we are looking forward to trying their chinese and Thai dishes too.

If your delivery person is not prepared to make money by doing delivery in bad weather, then don't!  It's fine that you cancel this after received my order. I've never met a delivery man saying the F word to a customer because of the bad weather. I didn't get even one word he said in the phone. I knew he came because I went to my window and saw a truck wandering. Since he knew the weather is bad, he should've understood I had tried my best to get dressed as soon as I could. The worst delivery experience ever.

Nice find! My friends in Bethel mentioned this place and we stopped for dinner. We ordered a couple of the sushi rolls and two entrees to share. They are very generous with portions here! Lots of leftovers. I think I ate enough for the entire week. They had a great variety of sushi and the rolls were delicious. Perfect ratios. Service was great. Our server was very friendly and attentive. It seemed like all of the employees there were in an upbeat mood which always makes an experience more enjoyable. I wish I remember which rolls we got but for entrees we got the sesame chicken and I asked for the mixed vegetables to be in a spicy sauce. The sauces on both dishes were perfect. The kind you want to drown your rice in but then you remember you're already stacking up the calories lol. We also got the vegetable lo mein which is probably the best I've had in awhile. I may have to make the drive here to come back because it would be worth it.

If you're looking for a place to get hot pot in Madison, then this is it! You get your own mini hot pot instead of a big communal one. There are different broths to choose from, I got the spicy Szechuan last time which was indeed spicy. You get a lot of food if you choose the combo so come with an empty stomach or you could probably even share between two people. I ordered the lamb combo and it came with an entire plate of lamb and then another plate of veggies and other hot pot goods like tofu and fish balls. They have a bar where you can get noodles and make your own sauces (as much as you like). They even have eggs! Crack an egg into your hotpot and poach it to your own liking. It's the best part about the hot pot I think.  The prices are pretty good and very affortable during lunch time as they have a lunch special. The place is run by a couple and their daughter (I'm assuming) last time I went. They are very friendly. I love supporting small family operations like this. What a cool addition to the Madison food scene.

Ordered takeout based on recommendations. Wonton soup had lots of wonton, but broth was tasteless. Egg rolls were hot and crispy despite the 20 minute drive home. Happy Family was tasty with a small lobster tail. The Moo Goo Gai Pan had plenty of chicken and mushrooms but was poached without any flavor of ginger or stir fry. The 75 cent surcharge for fried rice was worth it.

I will give them another chance but will not order the Moo Goo. We will probably eat in and BYOB.

I have tried this restaurant for couple times and I have been very very disappointed every single time. When the shop first opened, I tried a non-spicy noodle and it tasted like someone pulled the whole bottle of salt in it. Then I stopped coming to this place for almost a year, then I think I should give it another try so I ordered Î÷ºìÊÁ¼¦µ°°èÃæ (chow mien with tomato and egg). OMG! Can you actually imagine a bowl of chow mien with pieces of egg roll skins and ketchup? After that, I tried at least two more times but got no luck. Bye, I will never come here again.
Wasn't exactly the best, but not bad either.  The soup was a little salty, food portion was decent.
Fuck this place. Took 2 hours for my food to get here and they gave me the wrong shit and did it after closing so I can't call. Pissed as ever, never ordering from here again.

For a smallish restaurant that does Chinese, Thai, and sushi in Bethel Park, Rice Inn was a pleasant surprise. Inside what seems to be an old Pizza Hut, Rice Inn is nicely decorated and appears very clean as my first impression.

As for the food, my fiancee and I ordered the rainbow roll, the fantastic roll, and salmon and red snapper nigiri. The fish tasted quite fresh, and the rolls were neatly made. The service was very quick; we probably weren't waiting more than 10 minutes for our rolls, even though the restaurant was starting to get busy for dinner on a Friday night. I was expecting the fantastic roll, which was considered spicy, to only by seasoned with spicy mayo as many "spicy" rolls are, but the crunchy tuna was actually spiced inside the roll with a little more kick. It was *fantastic.* The rainbow roll was also delicious, with fish and avocado on the top of the roll, as opposed to all the fish inside the roll as some other restaurants make.

Overall, it was priced about the same as what you would expect from most sushi joints, ~$12 for a higher-end roll and ~$4 for nigiri. The waitress was friendly, and for the quick service and good sushi, I would wager we will be back soon!
Love How Lee! Would give it a 5, but lately my orders have been slower than usual to come out. Otherwise, this is some of the better fast-food Chinese that I've had anywhere.

I won't lie, I was a little nervous about going to a Chinese restaurant in an old Pizza Hut.  I was very pleasantly surprised!  The staff is very friendly and they have extensive options.  

There is a great sushi list and after sampling several of their selections, I have not been disappointed.  Rice Inn's Thai options are fantastic, the pad thai is some of the best I've had in the 'Burgh.  The portions are enormous, a little larger than necessary (doggie bags are necessary here).  If you order dishes with beef or chicken, you receive large chunks of fresh meat, not the small cuttings found at some Chinese restaurants.

Not to mention, this place delivers!

I recommend you give it a try.  This is a great place to go for a relaxed, reasonable, good meal.

After going here for about a thousand times, I finally realized I never reviewed this place. Sorry How Lee!!

Overall, great authentic spicy Chinese food. Just make sure you order from the very back/last page of their menu if you're looking for the spciy/authentic food. Some of the things I like to order everytime I go there include, the hot chilli pot (option of fish, lamb, beef, etc), ChongQing fried chicken (sorry I don't actually know the legit name),  beef boiled in spicy oil dish (again don't remember the English name, it's called Shui Zhu Niu in Chinese), etc. Bascially, most of their spicy food are pretty good!

However, I do want to point out, their stir fried potato dish is no longer as good as it used ot be! :( The last time I went, it was sliced as big as the size of my pinky (almost)!!! That was pretty disappointing. Hope they get that issue resolved....
But the good news is, this is not going to stop me from coming back (yet)! Just get your tissues/napkins ready to blow your nose!

And their service overall is pretty fast!

Tried out based on referral. Order with someone with poor English name "E" it didn't go well. I drive to get order, she claimed to be one of the owners... however she didn't make me feel like I should spend my money, when I ordered people overheard my comical conversation with her. She didn't seem to care about customer service, she just wanted my $$...based on that why should they get my $$... ordered canceled and now typing, I will never give them my $$ why should u?

A great place for hot pot with good broths and nice ingredients. I go about once a week and have found it consistently good. For those that go often enough, they will remember you and your preferences (like if you don't want scallions in your broth). 

Another observation... as someone who has eaten hot pot a lot in the past, I didn't really need a primer but on several occasions, I have witnessed the staff being very helpful to people who are new to hot pot. 

Glad to see a place like this in Madison!

I've given Rice Inn numerous chances and have been underwhelmed at each visit. I've tried the wonton soup, egg rolls, sweet and sour chicken, and stir fry general tsos chicken. While portions are large and everything has been served hot, those were the only positives. The entrees were bland, with one having barely any sauce and the other being smothered in sauce, making it soupy. The service was not overly friendly either. I've seen many positive reviews, so maybe I've just been there on off nights, but I do not plan on giving them my business again.
ordered general tso's and it was decent but it tasted like buffalo hot sauce-- not general tso's at all. Slightly disappointing

Great experience. The owner is friendly and very helpful. We initially wanted to sit next to our hotpot but he insisted we sit behind it. Surely as our table for four, but only with the two of us, began to fill up with bowls of sauces and things to cook, we saw the wisdom in this. We both chose the Schezuan broth, which was spicy enough to make me eat slowly but so good with the ala carte noodles, that I just had to keep on eating or feel the burn. The broth was too spicy for my husband, and the owner graciously took the broth back to tone it down. Every once in a while, our hot pots would be refilled with broth. The meat and fish we had was good and fresh. We also enjoyed all the extras, tofu, mushrooms, spinach, etc, that was included. 
Dinner took us about 1 1/2 hrs from start to finish. Plan accordingly. We went there at 5:30 on a weeknight and the restaurant was slowly filling up by the time we left. Leftovers can be taken home and make a great next lunch/dinner. 

Check out their FB page for more info. https://www.facebook.com/MiniHotPotMadison/

War Sui Gai is best I have had in years.  This was my first visit and I am impressed, definately will be returning and telling everyone I know to go there as we were just discussing that there 
are no good places anymore for Chinese food.  This is the place to go!
Linda
We love us some Rice Inn!!!  Sushi is on point, dishes are delicious!  Grab a table and try the pan fried dumplings...will not regret it!

We've eaten here a handful of times with family since it opened. Sadly, the portion of the starter platter of veggies, tofu, meatballs, etc., has been reduced to half the amount compared to when we first started eating here. Hot pot dinner prices have gone up $1 and now there is a $5.99 charge if you decide to share a pot. It's still more than enough food though.

Just your typical Chinese restaurant. I've asked the owner how long they have been open and they said it's been open for about 2 decades and there is a good reason why. 

From the moment you walk in, it laid out like every Chinese restaurant. The one thing that sets it apart is the quality (and the taste) of the food. Looking at the few reviews this place has (most over 2 years ago), I think this place serves the best Americanized Chinese food in Cleveland. 

My go to is the chicken & beef with broccoli and it is the best I've tasted. Their general tso chicken is pretty good too. They have a lot of options and I've never been disappointed by their food. 

I've talked to some of their customers and they come from as far as Eastlake and Beachwood just to get carry out. 

So if you are looking for a place to grab some Chinese, this place is it. Yes there are some bad reviews but don't judge a book by its cover. Go and try it out yourself!

Lunch special update: prices have risen about $1.50 per plate. Still tasty and filling, but definitely not as (financially) appealing as last time I came for lunch. 
If you're down to spend $8 for lunch (which still isn't a bad deal) How Lee provides quick service and dependable food. I don't think I'll be back for dinner though, since the price-to-quality ratio gets a little skewed when lunch specials end.
The egg roles were really good but the lo mein was over cooked and slimy, the chicken was stringy and tough, and the fried rice was flavorless.

Tonight was our last time to eat here.  While the food is very good the service is awful!!  It took us an hour to get basic meals.  Tables all around us that were seated after us received their food and we still sat waiting.  This happened a couple months ago and we just left.  We tried it again tonight hoping to give them another chance and the service was no better.  What irritated me the most is when my husband called the manager over she didn't really seem to care

Finally went here for the first time today and I'm kicking myself for not going sooner... and more often. The chicken thigh and shiitake mushroom noodle soup is my new favorite noodle soup in the area which says a lot for me because I dearly love noodle soup. The pork and cabbage dumplings were outstanding as well! Very fresh and flavorful. The hint of vinegar poured on top just made it perfect. The tofu and eggs were also amazing. We are very lucky to have this little gem in town and I will definitely be coming back and recommending it to others!

The food used to be better and you didn't have to fish the protein out of your main dish.  My problem is their lack of attention.  Food for two and you get one fortune cookie. Or they mix the size in your order....just frustrating by the time you get home and realize the mistake.  Not going back anytime soon

Took my chance again to have only half my order delivered as purchased.

How Lee is my favorite place to grab Chinese food in Pittsburgh.  The real gem here is their "Authentic Chinese" section of the menu, which features a variety of quality Sichuan dishes.  The service here is always prompt and friendly, the Sichuan dishes are always fresh, and I'd say it's a decent value price-wise.

I have a simple litmus test for Chinese restaurants, and it comes as a result of my 30 years of experience of eating at Chinese restaurants all over the U.S. (mainly California) and in mainland China.  My test?  "Kung Pao Chicken."  It's always the first thing I try at a Chinese restaurant, because I have experienced Kung Pao Nirvana, and I have had way too many disappointments.  A disappointing Kung Pao experience usually leads to "no second chance" from me because there are choices one can make.

When I saw the "grand opening" signs for Rice Inn at the old Pizza Hut location next to Walmart in Bethel Park, I didn't want to get my hopes up.  I actually waited until I saw a couple of Yelp and Urbanspoon reviews before I decided to get my dining partner to join me for a meal there.  (you can't be too careful these days...)  My first impression was, "HEY, they've actually dressed up this old Pizza Hut pretty well!"  They even managed to do something with those weird trapezoid Pizza Hut windows that we all know and love.  The place was simply decorated, and was very inviting to the first-time guest.  (maybe the odd familiarity added to that?)  Comfortable seating, low noise level, attentive hostess (who turned out to be the manager) and an eager young waiter all made us feel good about our choice to try Rice Inn from the very start.

The first thing we noticed on the menu were the letters "BYOB."  We immediately sent our young accomplice to the nearby Giant Eagle to procure some bottles for us.  I simply love the whole BYOB concept, especially when there is no "corkage" fee.  Upon opening the menu, I was impressed with the depth that it contained, and since I had read that this new restaurant had good sushi, I ordered the "Baked Alaska Roll" as an appetizer.  I am unable to resist any roll that has smoked salmon on it, and this one did not disappoint.  It was expertly prepared, very well presented, and the ingredients seemed fresh and tasted delicious.  The only bad part was that it was cut into 8 pieces and there were 3 of us, so I had to graciously (and reluctantly) deny myself a third piece!  This was an odd roll, because as the name implied, it was served warm.  But I really, really liked it, and so did my compatriots. (who got 3 pieces, unlike me...)

I was feeling great about this place almost immediately because we got to watch the sushi chef prepare our roll, and we got to drink exactly the beer that we wanted (Yakima Glory) instead of settling for the usual run-of-the-mill Chinese restaurant offering.  We decided to try a nice cross-section from the menu to find out where the strengths and weakness might be.

We ordered a seafood soup for two, an order of Kung Pao chicken with fried rice (only 75 cents to upgrade from the steamed rice) and an order of Pad Thai, of which we are huge fans.

In a word, the Kung Pao chicken was "perfect."  This is the dish that always lights me up when it is done correctly, and the kitchen at RICE INN nailed this one.  Tender, perfectly cooked chicken, crispy texture in the vegetables and nuts, and a sauce that was exactly what I was hoping for.  A++ and the best I've had in the South Hills of Pittsburgh.  The seafood soup got a B minus.  Everything was in there as advertised, and nothing in the soup was overdone or tough.  Obviously the kitchen used fresh ingredients.  But personally, I thought that the soup itself was somewhat lacking in seasoning and overall seafood taste.  This may be a personal taste thing, but I wasn't that excited about the soup.  My friends, however, enjoyed it more than I.  As for the Pad Thai, it was not what I was expecting.  I have had a lot of GREAT Pad Thai lately because this is one of the major strengths of one of my favorite restaurants located a few miles up the road on 88.  This Pad Thai needed to go back to the drawing board, in my opinion.  The shrimp was tender enough, and the rice noodles were just about right, but the seasoning of this dish just didn't do justice to the Pad Thai tradition.  After offering some feedback to our young and enthusiastic waiter, "Morgan," I wouldn't be surprised if the chef made some adjustments on this particular menu offering.  It's hard to do EVERYTHING well, and since this place has only been in business for a month, I'll expect some improvements on this one.

My overall impression could be summed up in these words:  "Do you have any TO-GO menus?"  I will definitely be coming back to RICE INN to explore the menu further and find out what other offerings on the menu are "in their wheelhouse."  It will not surprise me to find out that they do a lot of things well, based on this first visit.

I'd also like to make mention of the fact that the hostess who turned out to be the manager listened to the feedback we gave our young waiter on the food we were served, and she unhesitatingly removed the cost of the Pad Thai from our bill without any suggestion from us.  I really respect this desire to please!

The people here are so nice. The General Tso's is absolutely amazing and the sushi is great. We order delivery a lot and everything comes hot and really quickly! Their lunch sushi specials are a can't miss!

The meat was frozen but very thinly sliced and cooked well and tender, my cabbage had some black spots and the broth was very bland (had the coconut one). The additional portions are very generous- I added Bok Choy and enoki mushrooms. The sauce bar is a must since the broth didn't have much flavor- but that being said the sauce bar makes this place. I followed the basic instructions and it was very tasty. The server was very helpful in showing me how to do this. The noodles were very bland as well. I'd like to give 3.5 - I'm just not sure I'd recommend it as a four star place.

Good authentic Sichuan food. Between the two of us, we ordered Chongjin dumplings (spicy with a hint of sweetness, 3/5 stars), a fish chili pot (real spicy, 4/5), pork with bamboo shoots (4.5/5). Portion is just right for us.

We had heard that this restaurant was good and their parking lot is always full so today my family tried it. 
We were seated quickly because we got there right when it opened. Our waitress brought out drinks and took our orders as the place started to fill up. They had a nice sushi selection but because it was so cold outside we all were looking for warmth, we all ordered entrees. 
I ordered Happy Family (16.95) that had lobster, scallops, shrimp, chicken, beef and vegetables in a brown sauce. It was good but seemed a it salty to me. It was a huge portion and I only managed to eat half. 
My youngest son ordered Triple Delight (13.95). It had shrimp, chicken, beef, and vegetables. He cleaned his plate. He probably would have licked it had I allowed him. 
My husband ordered Hunan Shrimp (12.95). It was spicy but no overly so. He too cleaned his plate. 
My oldest son (who currently recovering from a tonsillectomy) had a bowl of egg drop soup and a bowl of rice. It would be kind of hard to mess up those things. 
We definitely will be back. I would like to try their sushi and other items on their menu. The most important thing to know is that it's BYOB.
I got the shrimp lo mein and an egg roll. Everything was delicious. There could have been more shrimp in the lo mein but it didn't take away from the taste of the food.

The service was nice and friendly. It was a lot of food for the price. But the food was the weirdest Chinese food I've ever ate. We had general tso chicken which was a container of smashed chicken breasts?  No flavor. Weird sauce. It was like microwaved Salisbury steak with red sauce. The pork lo mein had giant udon noodles mixed with random hunks of vegetables and it tasted like fish.

This is my third visit to this Chinese restaurant, and I will keep coming back!  The staff are very friendly, on the ball but patient, and repeatedly thank their customers.  The portions are healthy, the veges always fresh and crisp.  I had the General Tso's shrimp, not spicy, and it was wonderful.  The sauce is tangy and flavorful but not too sweet or pungent.  I also had an egg drop soup which was very good.  I'll be back!

Update - -5/30/17--prices are up for lunch to $13.95.  Serving sizes have shrunken noticeably. There seems to have been a chef or ownership change as well.  My Szechuan hot pot broth was not up to par and service was a little abrupt. New faces.

Five prior Yelp stars. Alas, now, three. 

If I was new to it, I would not make a trip or detour off of the road to stop here. But I will return at least for another visit or two out of my strong feelings of loyalty.  But I am starting to consider looking elsewhere for a new love, fickle as I am.  I deeply regret that I can no longer strongly recommend for other than a novelty or to reminisce.

We went in for lunch because of the 4 star rating. We stood waiting and staff would walk by us and not acknowledge us at all. We did not receive a "wait to be seated" or a "we'll be with in a moment". We just got ignored which is a disappointment because I was really looking forward to trying this place while in the area.
Stopped in during an informal campus visit. The food is great. The pork and cabbage dumplings were delicious. The noodles were excellent--wet and dry. Good price.
Food is not that bad 2 stars. But the delivery service is so bad and when u contact the restaurant they ignore you. It was a really bad experience even if food is good. I really not recommended.

Well the food was tasty but the first egg rolls I had to send back because it was cold in the middle and then that got me looking around at the bugs on the windowsill and the goop splattered on the wall night next to our table.
This is always my go to for Chinese food. Great service and portions. Some of the best Chinese food in the area as far as I am concerned

I visited location on October 20th around 7 p.m. and as I approached the cashier she was in the process of blowing her nose with a wet nap after blowing her nose and taking my money she then went back and started making  dumplings with her bare hands. This is the most unsanitary act I've seen in quite a while I will not be going back. To add this is how cold, flu and diseases are transferred.
Vegetable roll combo was a great price for the rolls you got. We also liked the egg roll. Byob is also a plus! Sushi was fresh. Service was prompt!

Just updating the review yet again. I feel like prices are a bit high for the amount of meat and quality here (but still LOVE the broth and sauces). I recently tried their different style dish on the hotpot menu, where you can choose your base and add to it per item. It was perfectly hot, spicy, and tasty and all of the ingredients were delicious. I also have tried the noodle soup here, and would definitely go for the hotpot over this.

Overall still a good place to take your friends, since everyone can have their own dish and it's clean and tasty.

The overall concept of the restaurant and food are great. 

The main factor that would stop me from returning is the customer service.  They were busy but the waiters only seemed confused for our table in regards to our order.  We had 3 combo meals (fish, beef and lamb) with coconut, kimchi and mushroom broth.  When the meal came out, they never gave us our lamb. When we asked for it, the waiter returned with our receipt and asked us to point out what was missing. If they already had time to correctly print out our receipt, they should also take the time to correctly give us our order.  I also never got the soda I ordered. We had to ask them to take the order off when we paid. 

The entire time we were there, we were never served water. When we asked for water, they only brought out one glass of water (there were 4 of us).  We had to ask for water again. The waiter brought out the water along with two plates of vegetables. He set everything down at the table next to us and then took the plates of veggies to the table across the room. He then came back to help other tables near us which resulted in him walking past us 3 times.  5 minutes later, we were served the waters that were set on the table across from us. 

I understand it may be a small family business but if they were taking time to talk and give free drinks to the table next to us, they could have tried a little harder to make sure our order was correct and serves us water as well.  Our table was the only one with no water. 

Overall, the best dish we had was the kimchi broth one. Mushroom and coconut broth literally only had coconut and mushrooms, very plain and simple. 

Best part about the restaurant was their varieties of dipping sauces available.

Huge portions amazing quality. General Tso's is best around. 

Normally you get rice under your chicken.. Here you get chicken under your rice.

Great food and friendly staff, I highly recommend dining here. The hot pot with lamb and the spicy broth is my favorite. You get to choose your own unlimited noodles to cook in the broth and create your own dipping sauce. They keep adding fresh hot broth to your pot as you eat. You will not leave hungry.
Excellent noodle house.  Fast.  Tasty.  Many variety.  High quality ingredients.  Best I have ever had.
Place has gone downhill in recent months.  I used to eat here a couple times a month, but after a run of bad experiences, decided to look elsewhere for Chinese.

Love this place. If you can't tell, my standard for Chinese food is how well a restaurant can do in the SGV in LA. And this restaurant would do quite well. 

The owners are very friendly. The menu is lacking in English explanations, but they are more than happy to explain to you how the menu works. One side of the menu is lunch and one side of the menu is the regular hot pot menu. 

If you've never had hot pot, the idea is a pot of broth is placed on your individual hot plate. You put raw veggies, thinly sliced meat, tofus, and whatnot into the simmering pot of broth. Wait for it to cook, then fish it out with your chopsticks or spoon, dip in some sauce and enjoy. If you've ever had the entree fondue at Melting Pot, it's that idea, but hot pot came first. 

For the hot pot menu, you can either order a soup base (5-6 different flavors including a mushroom broth, a szechuan spicy broth, and a spicy thai broth), and then pick the "side orders" you'd like to have for your hot pot, like meats, vegetables, tofus, etc. The soup base is about $5, and most of the side orders are about $2. But the better deal is the combo. With the combo, you have your choice of soup base, along with a particular meat, and it comes with a combination veggie plate that includes a variety of items like spinach, napa cabbage, tofu, enoki mushrooms, lapchang, corn, fish balls, and more. The combo is only $15 at night, and I believe they have a lunch special version for $10. There's also an all vegetarian combo, which you can order with a mushroom broth.

The sauces are on the side, and they're plentiful: minced garlic, cilantro, green onions, hoisin sauce, soy sauce, peanut sauce, fermented tofu sauce, oyster sauce, etc. There are also eggs and noodles for the end of your hot pot, but I didn't get a chance to partake because I was so full. 

The broth was so flavorful and delicious. I ordered the Szechuan spicy broth and it was certainly spicy. If you're not a spice person or only like a little bit spice, I wouldn't go with this one. Both my dining partner and I really enjoyed this meal. The service was fast (they keep the broth ready, and you do much of the cooking yourself), and very well priced. They're a bit of a trek being on Park Street, but they are well worth it.
Horrible service. They close at "10" but lock the doors and 9:30 and if you're waiting in line and they run out of food they don't make more you're just out of luck. Never again.

Decided to give this place another chance after staying away for over 10yrs.  Was let down again.  Ordered shrimp fried rice and paid for extra shrimp. Im convinced that if I had not paid for extra shrimp, this dish would have been mostly rice. Rice was bland, no egg or not one single veggie in the shrimp fried rice. The clencher?, dirty shrimp lots of them with the black entrail still in them.  Tray of at least 75 egg rolls just sitting out on counter, they take them from the tray to cook when ordered. 
Worst.Huge bowl of raw breaded chicken pieces { think sweet n sour chicken} just sitting under fryer on top of a crate , ready to grab a handful to cook as ordered. How the heck do you not care to leave these items out which should be kept cold until ready to cook. Food poisoning is real, people. And staff was not friendly.
Will not return even in another 10 yrs.
Update. Was pretty drunk...went again..the low mein noodles were disgusting, like the microwave stuff from dollar store...but everything deep fried is great!

We love hot pot and went here to celebrate our new house.  The server was probably the owner and she tried.  At least she was very pleasant.  The food was OK, a mixed bag, but pretty good overall.  I thought it was a little expensive for what we received.  The spicy broth had a somewhat greasy element to it which was a little offputting.  We literally had only one piece of several of the items.  The salad bar that was accompanying it was also a little lacking.

This place was OK, but we've had much better.  I hope they improve their offerings and make a go of it, but we'll try some place else next time.

I like this place.  For a one-off Chinese restaurant in Parma, it's tasty, has friendly service, and reasonable prices.   I especially like the large selection of Tofu dishes of traditionally meat dishes.    I did have 1 bad dish which was the Kung Pao Tofu.  Please avoid this dish if you don't like very large amounts of celery.   It was absolutely overwhelming.  BUT, it's not going to stop me from coming back!   Everything else I tried has been very satisfactory.

This is the new location for the old double 10 restaurant on University Avenue. They do individual hot pot, which is great, but for me the biggest and best news is the array of home-style dishes: spicy pork with dried bean curd, eggplant, and delicious homemade steamed dumplings.  We're glad you found a new place, and we're happy to be back!
Delicious and fun! It is a little pricey but I always have leftovers for another meal.

I've been frequenting this place since they opened a couple years ago with my family. I've also brought a few friends here. Sadly, the place has lost quality, quantity, and friendliness... Three attributes that used to make this place my family's favorite dining spot. We would go three times a week some weeks. They used to give enormous portions of everything. Something must have happened because suddenly we would go and we'd get these tiny plates. I used to enjoy their Triple Delight. Then they got extremely stingy with their portions. I would spend over 20 dollars on my meal and leave still hungry. I would tell myself that I am still getting quality food. Then their chicken became more and more fatty and gummy. Then I would go because my family became close to the wait staff and owners. Now I rarely see the owners and all of the waitresses we liked are either gone already or are leaving soon. The current wait staff doesn't know the menu and can't understand English. Plus they have a tendency of being downright rude. 

My family has already jumped ship and we've started giving other places our business.

Stopped by Champagne on a road trip. Ordered the handmade dumplings (14pcs) with pork and sweet corn filling as well as some small cold dishes. The flavor is really good and authentic. I really like their bean curd cold dish! The beef was also really tasty, definitely reminds me of home. Service was efficient, basically self served and the food was ready within a few minutes. Would definitely come back if I ever drive through Champagne!

So I'm updating my review to say that rice inn is still my favorite place for sushi and Asian cuisine! I've had the chance to try the pad Thai, love! And so many different types of sushi. The rice inn roll, mango roll, and eel roll are 3 of my favorites. Also pictured below! The service is always so friendly, and the prices aren't bad, especially for lunch. I'll be sad when I move out of this neighborhood and no longer have sushi less than a mile from me! Can't wait for my next trip or call in order to rice inn!

I think another reviewer accurately reviewed the location as blech....

In comparison to other places, the food was rather bland. I ordered the General Tso's combination platter, and none of the flavors "popped". It didn't feel all that fresh either. The chicken tasted like it might have been fried, and then fried again. The egg roll was bland as well. That went in the trash immediately. 

Also, when I went into the restaurant, it didn't seem like the cleanest of places - a woman had one one glove and was putting food into those little bags, then taking people's money and credit cards without removing the glove. When she went back to preparing food, she never changed her glove. Gross!

Needless to say, I didn't finish. I didn't save it either - it all went in the trash.

I won't be going back. If I recall, there is MUCH better Chinese up Lakeshore, near the Collinwood rec.

Delicious! The hot pot experience was new to me so this was a fun find. Easy parking with the parking lot. Affordable especially for the amount of food you receive. Most of all, the meal was delicious and the staff friendly without being overly attentive.

Oh my gosh! I haven't had Rice Inn Delivery since last yr and tonight I had Veggie egg rolls which were loaded and tasted like they were handmade so fresh& tasty!& I had moo shui Shrimp w pancakes so delicious! Fresh have leftovers for tomorrow. They don't disappoint you. Food is great and Ill order again next month- a lunch they give you a-lot of food check it out! Plus only place that delivers to my address- wish others did.
Best quality noodles on campus. Ordered beef brisket noodle soup. Definitely will come back again!

We have quite a few hotpot places in Madison but this one is one of its kind. I liked the individualized version of it. The colorful menu explains clearly what you need to do. We had lunch here and the selection was good. We chose Schzwan spicy broth and a kimchi broth. The sauces and sides u can select had a good variety as well. We had garlic, scallions, potatoes and rice noodle to add. The broth came to the table hot, it took seconds to boil. It's not a broth u want to drink up though but it flavored the ingredients well. 

We would come again for dinner to see the difference. Price wise- lunch was reasonable at $11.95 or $13.95 for seafood selection. 

Service was good as well. I am not used to waitress coming to table asking how u liked the food so it was a pleasant surprise. 

While we were there, the restaurant filled up fast. Most of them seemed like they have been there before. It's exterior doesn't do much justice to the inside. It was clean neat place. If u like hotpot- u must give this place a try.

The BEST Chinese food ever. I've been coming here for years and it's always been amazing. The portions are absolutely huge, more than enough to share or I get at least 3 meals out of one combo order. I normally get sweet and sour chicken or sesame chicken, but most recently I got orange chicken. The orange chicken tasted so fresh and the sauce literally tasted like it had fresh orange juice in it. A lot of take out places have sauces that are just sweet and gloppy but their sauces are fresh and thinner than other places I've eaten. The pork fried rice is the best I've had ever, so fluffy and delicious. Everything I've ever had is always hot, fresh, and has real ingredients. Even better, their staff is always very friendly, it's family owned. You can dine in, it's a really cute restaurant on the inside. Takeout is always fast and piping hot. Definitely try house of hunan!
Yes. Just yes. The broth choices are great, and they have plenty of great a la carte options. I am particularly delighted to get the fish tofu here.
Food is pretty good. Not fully authentic Vietnamese but close. Price is reasonable and service is good

Awesome authentic Sichuan style cuisine. Definitely a must try!

I recommend ordering from the authentic menu even for a first timer. It may seem overwhelming but the authentic food is amazing.

Avoid! I guess I shouldn't be surprised, but this is a typical Door Dash delivery ripoff. We ordered General Tso's Chicken, chicken fried rice and crab Rangoon. 30 minutes and $40 later we get a tiny bag of food. General Tso's Chicken is 3/4 white, mushy, tasteless rice - Where's the chicken? The chicken fried rice is just as mushy as the tasteless mushy rice which constitutes 3/4 of the General Tso's dish and tastes like it been sitting in a vat of sesame oil all afternoon. The Crab Rangoon is basically a bunch of deep fried wontons that taste like the same disgusting oil used on all the other food, with essentially no filling whatsoever. 

Time to start standing up to these rip-off joints. These food delivery services are just an excuse for the cheap restaurants to rip-off customers. Stop the madness.

We decided to try Double 10 Mini Hot Pot for an early dinner this past weekend. We had heard good things about Double 10 so were excited to visit. I was pleased that it exceeded all my expectations.

The location is in a strip mall on Park Street. Once inside, the restaurant is open, airy, and pretty plain. We were greeted immediately, welcomed, ushered to a table, and asked if we had had Hot Pot previously. Although my partner and I have, my sister and her husband had not. Our hostess explained how to order and said they would walk us through it when ready. We all ordered a combination platter and selected our protein and broth. There were I think around ten broths to choose from. Our hostess checked with each of us to see what spiciness level we wanted.

While our plates were being prepared, we checked out the sauce bar. It includes various prepared sauces as well as ingredients like garlic, cilantro, and chilis which you can add to each sauce. Valuable to us, it included a recipe for a dipping sauce which was fantastic! Coming up with my own sauce was daunting. Following the recipe to make this delicious sauce was awesome. There were also eggs, noodles, potatoes, sweet potatoes, and rice noodles which you could add to your hot-pot. Strainers were available which you could use to help lift your food out of your hot-pot.

Soon our hot-pots were delivered to our table. Each person has their own hot-pot and burner. Our host set our hot-pots to heat, explained what each ingredient in our combination plate was and offered tips on how long to cook each item.

The ingredients were all fresh and plentiful. The flavor in my szechwan broth was delicious and the perfect spice level. (I drank quite a bit of the broth when I was done w/my meal.) As I mentioned before the dipping sauce was outstanding.The noodles were hard to pull out of the broth and I didn't care for my partner's coconut broth which I found bland, but other than that is was a fun and delicious meal.

I've been to other hot-pot restaurants and the service and quality of this experience really set it apart. Our host and hostess checked up on us multiple times, they explained what to do and answered questions and made suggestions. Everything we needed was there. This was a great experience and I can't wait to go back and do it again.
Love the fantastic sushi! We go here often. They give you soo much food for your money. So many varieties.

If you want authentic Sichuanese food, come here. This is the best you are going to get outside of China.  Go with the authentic stuff on the back of the menu, that's where the good stuff is at.  Don't order the americanized crap.  This place has reinvented itself like a phoenix rising out of the ashes. 
The La zi ji (Chongqing Chili Chicken), shui zhu yu pian(Boiled Fish Slices), Hui Guo Rou (twice-cooked porkbelly), Gong bao ji (Kung Pao Chicken), and Fu qi fei pian are all very good.  
I would eat here every day if I could.

I have been disappointed with delivery food lately. Only bright side, Chinese food delivery was fast. Though even the delivery being fast can't make up for the poor desire of good food. I won't order again. The orange chicken and fried rice combo - the fried rice was hard, and the orange chicken had way too much breading (you could tell it was frozen). 
Will not order again.

Had the shiitake and chicken thigh noodle soup. The broth was excellent, along with the noodles. I also really liked the texture of the mushroom and chicken. Everything feels well cooked. The serving size is also fair, not too big but also not too small. I only wish that there were a few more toppings such as onions, and a larger amount of bok choy. Overall however a very flavorful and sized meal. I recommend coming here if you need a break or something, as the restaurant has a relaxing atmosphere.
Three times I've eaten the food here and each time I developed food poisoning! I'm a vegetarian and I ordered the pad Thai or a similar veggie dish each time. Just watch out!

This place looks scary from the outside because it is in a run-down plaza, but it is my favorite sit-down Chinese food in Parma.  The chicken is always crispy and fresh and the sauces have good flavors. I do have to take a star away, though because their egg rolls are lacking in flavor and substance.  Otherwise, I have enjoyed everything I've ever gotten there!

I'm visiting from out of town and wanted to have hot pot. I was unsure as I've heard so-so reviews of Asian food in Madison, but figured we'd give Double 10 a try as it had so many good reviews.

This is a great hot pot place. Good sauce bar options- the chili oil was delicious. The combo plate gives plenty of food, and there's no need to order extra noodles unless you want a certain type.

My picky boyfriend says too many chilis in the Szechuan broth and he wishes there was sacha.

I will definitely come back again!

I've only ordered take-out from here so I can't really speak to the environment. I can say that when I order I have food for 2-3 days, which I great when you are on a tight budget.  I enjoy the quality of the food, but it's nothing that I would go out of my way for. However, it is delicious enough that when I think of getting Chinese this is my first choice. I've ordered a lot off the menu and nothing has ever been too spicy, but sometimes does get a little bland. I keep chili paste and various hot sauces in my house so it's easily remedied. I do agree with another review... Gotta have the dumplings!

I order the A8 Chicken Thigh & Shiitake. Good noodles for the price. The bowl come with a lot of noodle, but not much of chicken or shitaki. The soup was very tasty. Would try again.

Follow me on Instagram: @tryatreat

Was so excited when I found out Madison had a hot pot restaurant! I'd only ever experienced the Convoy St. shabu shabu in San Diego, CA and could not wait to see how this would compare. So...I made plans, met up with my foodie partner in crime and we had lunch there yesterday afternoon. The service was friendly and the food exceeded my expectations. 

We each ordered the $9 hot pot lunch special...which comes with a plate overflowing with a variety of vegetables and meats...topped with your primary choice of meat (chicken, beef, pork or lamb). We were also given the option to select our own individual choices of broth. Based on previous reviews, I was torn between the kimchi broth and the Szechwan broth. We each selected the Szechwan spicy broth and ordered a side of scallops and a side of beef balls. 

Our individual hot pots were quickly brought out and we were also educated on how to operate the table burners. While our broths heated up, we made our way to the sauce bar towards the back of the restaurant. There was a very nice variety of sauces, fresh herbs, noodles and spices. I grabbed a bowl and made a dipping sauce concoction...no...dipping sauce masterpiece, filled a plate with uncooked noodles and we happily returned to our now boiling broths.

Our meat and vegetables soon followed and we commenced to eating...well, more like commenced to placing our food into the very aromatic boiling broth and then eating. 

As it takes a few minutes for your meats and veggies to cook in the broth, there was time for laughing, talking and catching up between two old friends while we dined. The hot pot was wonderful, the service was very friendly, and the prices were very reasonable... I believe this may now be one of my favorite eating spots in Madison!!

Dining Tips: 
- Don't forget to look up while you are at the sauce bar. It is very easy to miss the additional sauce and seasoning options sitting just above your head while you're focusing on making your dipping sauce masterpiece.
- Make sure to grab an extra plate or bowl from the sauce bar to use as a "cooling station" for the items you've removed from your boiling hot pot. *Insert hot pot items directly from the hot pot straight into your mouth at your own risk...lol...very hot!*
- Unless you are specifically wanting items such as shrimp or scallops...when ordering the hot pot lunch special...there is really no need to order extra items such as beef balls or veggies...unless of course you just want more than what they are already providing you with.
- The Szechwan broth is in fact spicy (which for me...is a good thing) and gets spicier as it cooks...which may not be good for those who can't or don't tolerate spicy foods very well. If spicy hot appeals to you...then you're good to go...but if you're looking for a little less spicy than you may want to opt for one of the other broths instead. 

Last but not least....ENJOY!!! I know that I did *Big Smile*

I have been eating around green street for more than 2 years and I really would like to say mid-summer lounge sucks!!

It was ok at the beginning but ever since 2018sp when they started to advertise and business got better. I have had 3 very bad experiences there. 1¡¢I used to like their handmade dumplings. I ordered one dish but after 40 minutes waiting ( and during that period I asked if my dish was ready and they said they were making it already) then they realized oh they forgot. Fine. 2¡¢I ordered hot spicy noodle a week ago and I realized the materials inside the dish were only 2/3 of what I had last semester. 3¡¢today I ordered hot spicy noodle with beef. Well it served fast, I guess within 10 minutes. But what I had was an almost COLD and NO FLAVOR noodle and beef. When I complained to the sales guy he didn't care. I guess with all of the advertising( especially in wechat) their business got better and quality became the opposite.

I would say I would never go there again.

ÒòÎªÈý´ÎÌØ±ð²îµÄ¾­ÑéÎÒ¾ö¶¨ÔÚyelpÉÏÐ´Ò»ÏÂ¡£

Great Asian Fusion restaurant- always clean! We usually get delivery and it's awesome. Our order is always packed nicely and correct. The sushi is really good, and the wonton soup. I think their fried rice is a little bland, but that could just be me. Definitely not cheap, but I'm okay with it because they do a good job with everything. Regardless, still 5 stars for service and consistent quality!

What a delicious treat! Solid 4 overall. 

Came with a party of 2 and shared the dan dan noodles as an appetizer. I could smell the aroma of the Szechuan peppercorn...mmmm.. and each bite leaves your mouth with just a hint of numbness. Not to fear - it's not too strong. Noodles also had a nice chewy texture. It's a medium sized bowl, but we ate only about half to save room for the entrees.

Had the saut¨¦ed chinese watercress - so yum as it was cooked just right to retain it's crispness. Watercress itself has a great natural taste to it already, and it was complemented with some flavorful garlic pieces and slight gingery taste.

Also had the chongqing dry hot chicken. I asked them to make it a little less spicy, so I'm not sure how spicy it originally is.. It was nice and crispy, covered with red chilis and sesame seeds. Yum! You can also get the chengdu version, which is unbreaded, so I wanna try that next time.

Thoroughly impressed ^_^ will come back, especially for those noodles.

Ok don't get me started!!! The Chingqing dumplings at How Lee are out of this world. Get adventurous and ONLY order off the traditional Sichuan style menu on the back page.

Favorite items: beef with Chinese hot pepper, stir fried green beans with no pork, Mala eggplant, chongqing dry hot chicken (get a big side of duck sauce for dipping), Sichuan style kung pow. 

The fried egg rolls here are *the best* in the city of Pittsburgh- so fresh.

I love going here- the service is great and the owners seem like very nice people.

The food used to be better and you didn't have to fish the protein out of your main dish.  My problem is their lack of attention.  Food for two and you get one fortune cookie.
