Other then placing the order I really like this place. I might even rethink Dragon Gate as my top choice.

We tried this place last night and are so very glad we did! Nice, clean place with a relaxed atmosphere. The waitress was good and didn't hover. I ordered the sesame chicken combo platter. Portions were good-sized and plated very prettily. That was one thing that surprised me, actually. Most Chinese places just mound it on a Styrofoam plate and call it good enough. Here, someone actually put some thought into it; I wish I would have taken a picture, but I was too hungry. :) The only complaint I have is the egg rolls were a little tough and chewy. We were given a small plate of quartered oranges for dessert, which was a nice palate cleanser, not to mention just plain tasty! I'm even more happy that they deliver to us in Verona-yay! We will definitely order from them again.

This isn't my go to place-- I only visit when I have a coupon. 

The Asian-themed choices are not so great. It's a good attempt without have an expensive. price (for a college campus). For example, with the Thai curry and the pad Thai, it's the right general direction for the flavor, but it just misses its mark. For more authentic Thai dishes, I would go someplace else. 

However, I still prefer the Asian noodle dishes over the Italian and other choices-- so if I did somehow decide to like Italian in the future, my opinion of this place might change after trying the other items. 

There are a lot of options, so I would take some time reading the menu that they have hanging on the right side of the line to the cashier. The menu behind the cashier doesn't have the same descriptions. Many items don't include meat, by the way-- it's an extra $2.50+. So if you do want a meal with meat in it, it comes out to ~$10+

The menu appears to be organized in a certain way that I really don't understand. The first impression is that it's sorted by price, however some items have different prices listed under them. (You'll notice what I mean when you're right in front of it.)

The workers have always been super friendly, and it's regularly filled with students, so I'm guessing they're doing something right. 

P.S. Sign up for their email list for BOGO free coupons.

I've been going here for a while and the employees have never been overly friendly or even motivated to do their jobs well. I went there today and my friend ordered the spaghetti and marinara sauce, and specified that she did NOT want cheese or meatballs on top, she even repeated this twice. So when they brought out our food of course there were meatballs on top. She told the man that she asked for no meatballs and so he brought it back, came back three minutes later with the same bowl of spaghetti except now it had 5 meatball indents where the meatballs had been... it was almost comical the way it looked. Did they really think this was acceptable? They didn't even ATTEMPT to make it look like they gave a sh*t about their presentation. So she brought it back again and asked him if they just took the meatballs off and he said yes, and she asked if she could have a whole new one because she's vegan and can't eat anything that has touched meat. So 25 minutes pass, still no food. When she goes over to ask where her food is, they tell her that they haven't even started making it yet. Meanwhile people who had come in 25 minutes after us were getting their food already. So by the time she finally got her pasta we had been there for an hour. The worst part? The girl who had messed it up in the first place was laughing at my friend as if she was an idiot or doing something wrong. Very poor customer service. So disappointed and will not be returning.

µÚÒ»´ÎÀ´µ½Õâ¸öµê£¬»á¸øÈËÒ»ÖÖ»Ø¼ÒµÄ¸Ð¾õ£¬ÀÏ°åÄïTinaÈËÃÀ£¬°®ÁÄÌì£¬ÊµÔÚÓÖºÜ»áÕÒ´ýÈË£¬ÃÔÈËµÄÑÛ¾¦Ð¦ÆðÀ´¸øÈËÒ»ÖÖ³õÁµµÄÎ¶µÀ£¡·¹Á¿´ó£¬Î¶µÀºÃ£¬ºÜ¾«ÖÂ£¬ÓÖ¿´µÄ³öºÜÓÃÐÄ£¬Ò»¿ÚÏÂÈ¥£¬Ò»ÃëÖÓ¸øÄã´øµ½Ì¨Íå£¬¶øÇÒ»ØÎ¶ÎÞÇî£¬ÌÏÌÏ²»¾ø£¬Á¬Ãà²»¶Ï£¬Ò»·¢²»¿ÉÊÕÊ°£¡Ting' Kitchen£¬ÄãÖµµÃÓµÓÐ£¡
The dish we order is frozen inside(not even cold! it is frozen) and guessing microwave is good in a restaurant level dish.

To me this is one of the best Chinese restaurants in Pittsburgh. The current owner, Tina, took over the old 'China Star' a few months ago and is gradually transforming it as a 'new Chinese' restaurant that mixed Sichuan and Taiwanese food. They are developing new cuisines every month. Tina's new ideas always make me happy and inspire me as well. For Chinese students, if you want some food not in the menu, definitely ask Tina. As long as she has food materials, she will cook for you.

I tried two dishes at this place. Not very authentic taiwanese food. Popcorn chicken was dry and didn't taste fresh, more like they were frozen. The batter was wrong. BBQ beef stir fry on rice was totally missing the taste of satay sauce. It was just taste like soy sauce or oyster sauce stir fry. Really need improvement.

For me, Noodles & Company is a nice change of pace, with a good variety to satisfy most people in your party.  I've been here a couple of times, as well as locations in other cities.

I don't disagree, Noodles  may not be the best value for a college student.  Good thing I have a job!  I appreciate the variety offered, with standard American fare (mac and cheese, meatballs) to Asian flare (Japanese noodles, pad thai).  Granted, none of the bowls will astonish you in the taste bud department, but I think it's a nicer option than your other Forbes Ave. choices, such as Chipotle, Primanti's, or Five Guys.

I like noodles and company and I enjoy their food. However, I have one major complaint. They focus too much on the noodles and not enough on the vegetables. 

Sure it's a pasta/noodle joint, but when I order "whole grain linguine with balsamic, olive oil, white wine and roasted garlic, red onions, tomato, spinach and parmesan or feta" I expect to get just that. Out of all the times I've gone, which is about 5, my meals have lacked vegetables. Maybe one or two pieces of tiny broccoli, 3 spinach leaves, or just even a few chunks of tomato. I enjoy the vegetables and they should be present in the dish, but they aren't. 

I may be expecting too much since I'm a vegan, don't worry I didn't order cheese, but they list vegan and vegetarian items on their menu so they should be more sensitive to us. This is something this location definitely needs to work on.

1) Add their Facebook page as they frequently have discounts only for Facebook fans.

2) Come here on the 1st of every month to have a $2 discount on your doodle (must be a regular cup).

3) If it's not the first day of the month, order something on the Special Menu instead of creating your own to save some money.

In my opinion, it's still a bit pricey considering you can get a Naruchan instant noodle from County Market for 20 cents.

I like the #5 Pho Bo on the Special Menu, but you have to make sure to pour the hot water evenly and slowly on top of the steak slices to cook them thoroughly. Add Hoisin Sauce and Srirancha too.

Besides, they make their smoothies from real fruit and their milk green tea is really good.

I also love the MUSABI rice on the sushi bar too.

I've been craving dumplings like crazy and stopped in for takeout. I got the steamed dumplings and chicken fried rice. Food was hot and it only took between ten and fifteen minutes, price was fair when it comes to this type of food. The dumplings were really good, pork and cabbage, although i was hoping for more cabbage! The chicken fried rice was good too, probably the best I've had in the area. It was also clean and nice inside the restaurant. I would definitely order again

The rice looked so delicious, but it ended up being so dry.  No egg in it.  The chicken in the Chicken Teriyaki is pretty delicious.  My wife loved the shrimp.  She really loved the spring rolls, just what you would expect from a mall restaurant.   Nothing to write home about.  I really wish they had Beef and Broccoli, but it may not have been as good either.  :(  But if you are staying in the hotel it will be fine for you.

Not great, but not bad, this little Chinese restaurant next to the Johnson Bank building does the trick if you want some average Chinese food for a good price. Also, I have to admit that I was surprised at how OK their sushi was -- I was definitely expecting to die from it, but actually sort of enjoyed it (don't make fun of me for admitting to that).

There are coupons printed right in the menu for free stuff depending on the cost of your bill, so the wife and I were able to get free spring rolls with our meal.

The food is amazing, nothing else needs to be said about it. Good deals, great value, fresh and tasty etc etc...

But would get more stars if the owner knew how to run a better business. Sets arbitrary hours, opens and closes whenever he feels like it. Loses business constantly because of his "whenever I feel like" attitude toward store hours. I've seen people mistakenly walk up to a locked door on days the place is randomly closed. Oddball hours of operation, to put it simply. 

If the dude has other commitments in life that requires him to constantly close at 3 in the afternoon before dinner rush on weekends, then he shouldn't have opened up a restaurant. 

If you don't subscribe to Doodle's Facebook feeds, you might be welcomed to a locked door at any given time you are hungry. 

I get it, it's a college town turned ghost town on weekends and holidays when the trust fund baby students run home to mom and dad and it becomes a chore for businesses to get people to come. But for the rest of us who don't have a family 2 hrs away from Champaign to mooch off of every weekend, it would be nice to get Doodles when we get hungry, like any other fast food place in town.

Also, not quite sure how the "now delivering" option would be effective, he just goes within a block radius on his bike. If you live above Doodles, you're probably the only people he can deliver to.

Having ranted all that, the food is very delicious, I try to go as often as I can (when it's open), worth every penny.

This place is amazing! Everything is made fresh to order. Have patience with the service and you'll get great food in return. The Peking duck was crispy yet tender and juicy. With the scallions and hoisin sauce, it makes the perfect Asian wrap! The Kong Pao Duck stir fry was so delicious! The fresh veggies paired well with the sweet tangy homemade sauce and the duck was of course cooked to perfection.

Great concept, could use some refinement. 

I had the shoyu doodles. Didn't get any toppings because I wasn't hungry at all since I already had lunch. I only got it because I wanted to try it. It's cheap at $1.70, but again, it's ramen noodles.

The shoyu broth was surprisingly good. I expected it to be one of those low-quality broth powders but to my pleasant surprise they actually concocted their own shoyu-paste. I believe it was topped with cilantro and garlic.

The noodles, however, were just your typical cheap 10 cent top-ramen that I didn't like. Don't get me wrong, I LOVE (imported) instant ramen noodles and I eat them almost daily which is a horrible idea, but I just don't like the oily, saturated fat-ridden 10 cent top ramen noodles. They're cheap for a reason. 

If you add toppings, the total price should come out to be around $3-$4 which is cheap for lunch, but expensive for ramen noodles. For deals-conscious college kids, $3-4 range can get you many things; 2 huge slices of "gourmet" pizzas on monday at Antonios, a philly cheesesteak at Penn Station (their Nov-Dec promotional price), hotdogs/brats at the beef stand, etc. I don't know if Doodles can rival these deals on the quality of food just yet.

I would love if doodles have more noodle options (i.e. vermicelli, egg noodles, udon, etc) and kinda turn it into a make-your-own-noodles place. I don't think it should be that much more expensive. I would love to come back to doodles, but right now, the top-ramen is keeping me away from it.

By the way, they also have sushi rolls and summer rolls. I haven't tried them yet, but they look pretty standard.

Was looking for some noodles in my area and Ting's had great reviews so I gave them a shot.  Their egg rolls are to die for! They are super huge and priced perfectly. Definitely recommend Ting's 100%!

Unfortunately I'm going to judge Noodles & Company a little tougher than I normally might because the Thai/Asian market in Oakland is well represented and if you want people's business then you really need to step up your game.

Here is one thing I really appreciate at Noodles and Company - the caloric value is listed for each dish.  Talk about an eye opener - if you don't choose wisely, you better have a date with the gym later in the day because there's a dish on the menu (fettuccine) that is over 1,200 calories.  

I had the Bangkok curry on my visit today and I thought the flavor was nice, not overpowering for a curried dish, and it was a nice size portion.  The caloric count wasn't bad and I felt full.  

My colleague who dined with me did a soup and salad combo and said that the spicy Caesar chicken sandwich was indeed spicy.

This is not my go to noodle destination, but, it's not on my list of "don't ever come here again" noodle places.  I'd describe it as, "it is what it is", nothing to write home about but nothing to write a bad review about either.

It's part of a chain. Their main specialty is noodle dishes with different twists along with three choices of sharable appetizers and soups. The noodle dishes themselves come in two different sizes (small or regular), the appetizers, and the soups themselves also have two different sizes, each at different prices. Depending on the season they might rotate a couple noodle dishes in here or there for a limited time (seasonal). While I found the selection of noodle dishes rather plentiful, I can't help but feel that the noodles themselves are at best average, especially for the price that I'm paying and considering that I can get better noodle dishes at surrounding joints for cheaper prices. Although I haven't tried all of menu choices, my favorite noodle dish is the spicy korean beef noodles. There's something nice about the simplicity of the dish, the sauce used in the dish is wonderfully tangy (though labeled sweet and spicy, it's actually not that spicy at all) the taste of it is a wonderful reminder of my Asian roots. In general, some of the other dishes tend to be more heavy in calories and biased towards Italian roots, which kinda kills the variety even though there are so many menu items. The cheesy garlic bread is pretty dope as an appetizer and the marinara that comes along with it is good. Location itself is well-kept and clean. Just be aware that it's near campus so it's usually busy during normal meal times (lunch and especially dinner)

This is the real thing foodies.  A jewel stuck in the middle of a random strip mall in Pittsburgh.  This is not a typical Chinese restaurant (although they do the American Chinese stuff fine).  This is a straight up Szechuan and Taiwanese powerhouse.  Tan Tan noodles are ridiculously good.  Red Chile Dumplings are a come to Jesus experience.  If you love that tongue numbing feeling of real Szechuan peppercorns you must try the Boiling Fish soup or Triple Pepper Chicken.  These are not dishes dumbed down for an American palate, they are full of heat and flavor.  Do yourself a favor and resist the urge to order from the typical Chinese menu they offer and stick to the Szechuan and Taiwanese offerings. You won't be sorry.
That's awesome. It is really traditional Taiwanese food. Recommend all my friends come here to have a try.ÀÏ°åÄïÈË³¬¼¶ºÃ£¡Î¶µÀºÜÔÞ£¡ºÜÕý×ÚµÄÌ¨ÍåÐ¡³Ô¡«

I had the teriyaki chicken. Perhaps I ordered the wrong item because is was swimming in teriyaki sauce and was just overwhelming for me.  The rice and veggies were just ok. Nothing special.  I would try this place again just a different dish.

I think there are only two words to describe what is Sakura, value & chaos. Sakura is located in a tiny little spot in the middle of the 5th Street Arcade downtown. I love the location because of the small shop atmosphere  in the Arcade and the wide mix of people who frequent the building, plus it's close to my work. Sakura is in the tiny "food court" of the building and is really a gem. I bring up "Chaos" to describe Sakura because that's what your experience is like when waiting in line for your food. 3 ethnic Asian guys are running the place, 1 cooking, 1 preparing to go boxes and the other guy taking orders and grabbing drinks. The typical person comes here for the "hibachi" style meal of Chicken, Steak, Shrimp or Veggie Teriyaki. The prices are wonderful ranging from $5.99 to $6.75 for an entr¨¦e. They do serve sushi and combo meals but I tend to stick with one of the main four.
 
The line is always a pain in the butt at lunchtime (I have been there a handful of times between 12 and 130) and it is always busy during these times. You wait and once your order is taken it is almost becomes a no holds bar death match to get in another line and fight for your food. I've seen it look like a Royal Rumble on one particular occasion. Eventually someone will get you your food but sometimes it is a struggle.
 
The food though! You get a fresh protein with a heaping side of white or fried rice and veggies (lots of onions, zucchini and mushrooms). Oh and that YUM YUM sauce to add really makes this meal fantastic and filling. Don't get me wrong it's not better than say a top hibachi place but for $5.99 how the hell can you beat that. What can I say I enjoy the food, the line is a pain but well worth in my opinion the best VALUE lunch spot downtown.

While David may have beaten me to my coveted first review, I still have a bit to say about Doodles.  Oh Doodles, you are delicious, and work well on a simple concept--cheap easy ramen with great ingredients making a quick yet portable meal.  Right now the space is very very new, making it seem a bit more like a lunchtime speakeasy than a dining establishment, but I'm sure it'll be more amenable soon (chairs are forthcoming, Shai promises!).

For $1.75-$4 you can get delicious ramen bowls with great ingredients.  I had the shoyu doodle with spam and a hard boiled egg.  I like shoyu, and I freaking freaking love spam, so it was a wonderful choice.  The only thing?  I might need double spam next time.  No, scratch that.  I WILL need double spam next time.  Which will probably be tomorrow.  Damn you , Shai, with your delicious noodly spam goodness.

Since they've become Ting's Kitchen, they've become our new favorite spot to eat. My husband and I LOVE their Cumin Lamb. Perfectly seasoned and just SO good! Their menu has a huge array of dishes to select from.

If you're looking for an authentic dinner, I'd say stop here for sure. Their service is always great and the atmosphere inside is perfect for a casual night out to dinner or a date night dinner.
Soooo good.    Tastes like Vancouver Chinatown food.   We enjoyed the barbecue beef and house fried rice.

I really really like this place, most in part due to the service here. The food is good and fresh (we were told they go out to get produce for service daily) as well. Our waitress was very attentive and had a fantastic knowledge of the menu, eagerly recommending various dishes and offering her input on substitutions if asked. I had the Beef Ramen Soup and the fried Grouper, and strongly recommend both. 

*Warning: If you ask for something that they don't think will accompany your dish well, they will you in a very "straight to the point" sort of way. This isn't meant to be insulting, roll with it and insist if you are certain that's what you want.
Food was good.fresh veggies. I enjoyed it. Price was right. Service was good. I would go back.

Very authentic Asian food! The pork ribs & winter melon casserole is super super delicious. Pork belly is really soft and tasty. They also offer unique Taiwan-style street food. Great restaurant in Pittsburgh!

eOn my first visit I tried the Japanese pan noodles with shrimp and made it a triple combo with a small bowl of the thai curry soup.  

The thai curry soup was actually quite delicious with pieces of spinach, mushrooms and carrots but the noodles were a little undercooked making them hard and almost unpalatable.  The pan noodle in the small portion is quite small and the sauce was good (super salty!!) but but the noodles were on the dry side.  The shrimp were a little gross, they weren't fresh and had the weird taste that cheap frozen shrimp have.  There were about 6 small shrimp in the dish. 

On my second visit I ordered the pad thai and was completely disappointed.  There were barely any pieces of egg and what was in the dish were dried precooked pieces of egg that were thrown in when the dish was assembled.  

This place is unique in that it offers many different types of pasta and noodle dishes but it is far from authentic when it comes to the Asian choices from what I've tried so far.  The novelty of this place has caught Oakand's attention as this place is constantly busy and always has a line during peak times.  It is convenient and relatively fast and the prices are on par with the panera across the street.  But I highly recommend that Pitt students and others take their money to the numerous small businesses in Oakland.  Noodles & Company is a chain that tries to grasp authenticity but never quite makes it there.  I suggest Lulu's noodles on Craig street for pad thai, their scrambled eggs for the pad thai are made to order and not scant in quantity like in N&C's meager and almost pitiful dish.  

I looked on their website and they do offer a free meal to people who sign up for their email list on their birthday, I signed up as my birthday is in a few days.  I find that I will probably frequent this place more than I honestly wish to.  I gave this chain three stars for the convenience, speed and overall package of this place; at least its not another mcdonalds.

BEST Chinese in Cleveland! I continue to make the mistake of trying to find an equal. I haven't come close. The family ownership of Wah Fu must be the missing ingredient everywhere else. Can't wait for my next visit.
Visited for the first time yesterday and was really impressed. The food was delicious, the wait staff was courteous and attentive and the decor was beautiful.

Ordered two chicken dinners last night for delivery and it never showed up, I didn't even want to waste my time and call them to complain. Do yourself a favor and order elsewhere, this is far from the first problem my family has had with them.

Compared to some other reviews on here, I'd argue that Doodles really isn't that overpriced. You can get a pretty filling lunch here for 5 bucks or under. Additionally, the add-ins they give you with your ramen are served in substantial portions. The add-ins themselves are of great variety and offer things that aren't too easy to come by at other Green Street restaurants like quail eggs or Thai fish cakes. They also offer several pre-configured 5 dollar combos that offer lots of add-ins. Additionally if you're really bothered by eating top ramen noodles, get the #10 Fen Si Doodle- it's got bean thread noodles instead of ramen!

You can find very delicious and transitional Taiwanese food in here. The dining environment is very suitable for lovers and friends.  
ÀÏéÄïÈË³¬ºÃ³¬Õý£¬Ê³ÎïÒ²³¬ºÃ³Ô£¬ÎÒÃ¿¶Y°Ý¶¼þÈ¥¡£¶øÇÒµ½ß@ÑeÓÃ²Í±£×C×ÄãÓÐ»Øµ½¼ÒµÄ¸ÐÓX¡£

Really delicious and authentic Taiwanese style food with very reasonable price! We enjoyed the meal a lot! Tina was very nice and friendly to us. We had traditional Taiwan pork rice, salty and crispy chicken, turnip cake, stir fried string bean and lamb there. They all taste awesome. And their steamed branzino fish is very good!!

The yelp reviews definitely deceived us!  Upon entering there was an odor in the restaurant. 
I wanted to leave but my husband said he wanted to give it a try. 
It is definitely not authentic. The chinese good is catered to American style.  We tried to choose the authentic Chinese food dishes to try, it was a mistake.  If you go- i would suggest ordering lo mein, chicken & broccoli, and etc.

Adding to my prior reviews.  The curry. The curry is my new obsession. Giant, protein focused, $10/$11 portion that Tandul in Tremont can't even touch. What truely amazes me Is their ability to make a non-spicy curry, while still retaining its creamy, comforting, delicious taste, and texture. Of course silly me, I forgot to ask for  no  spice this time. So in 15 minutes I'll be heading back to get my free replacement. I recommend this with noodles on the side instead of rice.

Great food and service. Very happy to find this place.

Tea smoked duck, it's flavorful and tender.

Steam fresh oysters was great, very yummy.

I would highly recommend this restaurant

Some days this is me favorite place to order Chinese and other nights I'm left disappointed. My main complaint is the inconsistency. I always order the same meal and i never know what to expect. Even when I'm left disappointed, the food is good but not excellent.

Very inconsistent and rude service when picking up. Again we try to support our local places but they seem to have a sense of entitlement don't get it. Saw another review about lousy general tso , I've ordered it the last couple of times and has been bland no meat or very bitter, or I got a chow me in dish instead that went in the garbage. Good luck,used to be good even if hostess is moderately hostile.

Read a few reviews that the food was generously-sized and delicious. Everyone was right! Enjoyed our anniversary dinner there. Nice atmosphere, unassuming location in a little plaza. Service was good and quality of food was good too, so we wondered why they didn't have more tables filled. My guess is that not only was it a week night, but the location is a little out of the way and you have to know about it.  I've gone to stores in that plaza and never known it was there before. Food was very well portioned and delicious! Authentic too... and worth the reasonable price. We'd definitely go back!

Have been searching for a new Chinese restaurant. 2 weeks ago found Aristo. We ordered the General Tso and the Sesame chicken. Fried rice, egg rolls and hot and sour soup.  They were having their 'soft' opening as they must be fairly new.  The food is out of this world good!  Egg rolls were stuffed with pork etc.  fried rice was so flavorful i ate all of it. General Tso was the dark spicy sweet sauce which is exactly what i like and have had a hard time finding elsewhere. They prepare several styles of food like schnitzel.  I will definitely go back to try their non-chinese meals.

This is one of my favorite chinees ressturants to go to you will not find mall quality food here. I usually get sesame chicken its always a nice crisp coating to the breading unlike if you go to a hole in the wall its always soggy breading the employees are always very respectfull and curtious to their customers a very nice family owned resturant and the decor is pleasant to see then alot of resturants ive seen.

Some of the best Chinese food I've had in years. Expansive menu, large portions, great service - albeit a misleading name.
Sesame chicken was crunchy on the outside, yet tender in the middle. Calamari perfectly cooked with a slight kick to it. Small yet yummy fried dumplings. I highly recommend this place.
This place has GREAT fresh Chinese food.  They are newer so a little slow at times but so worth it!!

I stopped in here for lunch a couple of weeks ago on the advice of some co-workers.  Overall, it was an ok experience.  Not the best Chinese food I've ever had, but it it was a solid entry for American-style Chinese on the west-side. 

The service was a little slow, but it was the lunch hour and it was pretty busy, so at the very least the delay understandable.  The prices were comparable this type of place - lunch specials in the $6-7 range with other dishes running a bit higher.  

Other than that, there wasn't anything remarkably good or bad about Wah Fu which is to say if you are looking for decent Chinese in the area it's worth checking out.

I am not sure why this restaurant got such great yelp reviews. There was a total lack of flavor all around and the Szechuan dishes weren't spicy at all. It's overpriced and the service is mediocre. I'm very disappointed.
Best Chinese restaurant in the area. That's why I give them 4 instead of  5 star is the price is a little stip.
Recommended by a local friend. This restaurant serves the authentic Sichuan spicy food. You will also be surprised by some 'secret' Taiwanese food cooked by the owner!

What can I say about this place. Staff are rude and don't really show a need to cater to the guest. They seem to have the mind set that "who cares if you never come back" so I will definitely not come back. Now if customer service isn't important to you, the food is pretty good. So you might actually enjoy this place. For me....3 stars

Excellent food from a wonderful place. I've worked in Asian restaurants for the past twenty five years, and this little place in north hills is fabulous. They have some of the best Taiwanese food anywhere in the Pittsburgh region, in addition to some of the more mainstream staples that you've come to love and expect in your neighborhood Chinese style restaurant. 
Stop by this place and sample from their diverse menu, or order takeout or delivery if you're near by.
You won't be disappointed.
This is the most delicious Chinese food in Pitts!!The food is authentic really Taiwan flavor.

I have visited this quaint restaurant a handful of times, and every time I really enjoy it! Everyone who works here is very friendly, they are also very knowledgeable about the menu and give us recommendations. Every dish I have tried here is delicious, the seasoning is always perfect. This restaurant has a large menu, if someone in your party does not care for the Asian menu items, they also offer some European foods such as pasta and spaetzle. The portions are generous, we always bring some food home. I enjoy Aristo Bistro and will return often!

Came here for the first time for dinner on a weeknight.  Ordered the woodear mushroom appetizer, the stewed pork belly over rice, and stir fried watercress.  Total came out to a little under $30 without tip.

What's Hot
- Quality.  Delish!  Cali girl here who grew up with home made Chinese food.  I've also eaten the real stuff overseas.  Trust me, dudes, I know!  The food was absolutely delicious and flavorful.  The stewed pork belly was tender and melt in your mouth.  The flavor/marinade was absorbed in the belly fat, which melted in my mouth.  The woodear mushroom was well seasoned with sesame oil, raw minced garlic, and chili oil.  Flavorful, not too spicy but had a kick, and crunchy yet tender.  The stir fried watercress had a good amount of sliced garlic on it and it was not overly salty, which is super important, because the freshness and flavor weren't masked.  Good quality Chinese food is hard to find, especially when it comes to certain dishes.   
- Layout.  There are booths and tables that can accommodate groups.  From what I could see, their largest table probably accommodates 8 people.  I came by myself after work, bringing work with me.  They sat me at a booth, which allowed me to spread out my work.
- Menu.  Not Asian fusion, which is something I appreciate.  Good variety, especially when it comes to Taiwanese dishes.  Many of the dishes on the menu are not common dishes, such as woodear mushroom, za jian mian, pork belly dishes, tendon, etc...  Their menu is also written in Chinese, which I appreciate.  Their staff and much of their clientele are native Chinese speakers, as well.  No offense, dudes, but in my experience eating at ethnic restaurants, the best ones are when the staff speak the language and personally know and eat the dishes.    
- Location.  Convenient location surrounded by other shops and restaurants.  It's in a conveniently located plaza with a large parking lot, which is helpful.  However, I'm certain that also means that this place could get busy during "rush hour".  So, be prepared.
- Service.  I came by myself and brought work with me, so I was eating and working at the same time.  However, the wait staff didn't push me.  It helped that the restaurant wasn't crowded, but that they didn't push me out was still appreciated.

What's Not
- Price.  The stewed pork belly over rice is $6, but the stir fried watercress is $13.  That surprised me.  My total tab was around $30 for 3 dishes, which seemed a bit high.  To be fair, fresh produce is more expensive.  On the other hand, you are paying for good quality.  
- Portions.  I was surprised the pork belly over rice was as small as it was.  For $6, it wasn't that bad.  However, it looked like the portions at this restaurant are not so much family size.  If you come in a group, be prepared to order more food to feed everyone.
- Service.  After I paid my bill, they pretty much left me alone.  They didn't refill my water glass or anything.  I've been in restaurants where we stick around after paying the bill, but the wait staff will still check in and refill water glasses.  That I didn't get that bummed me out.  Just goes to show that every restaurant is different.  

Final Answer
Definitely plan on coming back.

Good authentic food with a gigantic menu. I feel they literally serve any kind of chinese food here. This is not like chinese take out but more if a sit-down dinner. The pork shank is out of this world! It is soy-sauce braised and take a long time to make so get it here! The beef noodle soup is pretty tasty. The broth is really well made but I wish there was more toppings. I would bring people here for a nice meal targeting family-style so everyone can try different foods. Good find in the north hills.

Great food, very nice ambience and decor is updated and quite modern. Food was delicious, delivered quickly and ample servings. Would definitely recommend for anyone local to stop in for quality food.

First time at Ting's, so I hope it was just an off night, although I suspect it's just that I don't like their food. Almost completely empty on a Saturday evening at 7, which seemed strange. Our server was nice.

Appetizer of cold sesame noodles was inedible and nothing like any cold sesame noodles I've ever had. Overcooked Italian linguine noodles with a sour, soy-based sauce and some sesame seeds. It was truly terrible. Thankfully, they were removed from our bill.

Replaced with Dan Dan Noodles, which varied greatly from others I've had elsewhere. Basically a small bowl of noodles with oil and hot pepper flakes. Edible but nothing special.

Pot Stickers were bland and so completely burnt on the bottom that the taste was nearly ruined.

[At this point, we're thinking of cancelling the entree and just cutting our losses, but we didn't]

Split an entree portion of Mongolian Beef -- again, not like I've had in other restaurants. Some beef (that was of a decent quality) and a whole heck of a lot of white onions (and no other vegetables) in an overly thick and sweet sauce. We left about 70% of it uneaten.

A great disappointment.
Friendly staff; but terrible food...honestly.  I wish I could write good things about the food but it just wasn't.  Sorry.  I am simply hoping I don't get sick. :/

I stopped by Sakura recently to try something different. I've never eaten here before and I've always wondered why they have one stand that sells Chinese and Japanese food. To be honest, it doesn't seem like Sakura differentiates their meals that much. It's the same person making similar food, except half of it sells at one counter and the other half sells at another counter.

I ordered mushroom chicken with a side of veggies and it took a while to make. The food was of good quality and great taste. The staffer was friendly, but the wait was long. 

I'd definitely eat here again.
Excellent quality chinese food! Had the pork lo mein, Kung Pao Chicken ( HOT, its legit has mini peppers/chilis in it) and hand made egg rolls. Cant go wrong!

If there could be a minus review I would have selected that. The egg roll was dripping in grease on the outside and full of really old celery on the inside. Gross. The $10 General Tsoa chicken came with three peices of chicken and the cashew chicken was full of celery again. Will not eat there again.

If you like bland tasting chinese food, then i have the place for you. 
The food did come out hot, so thats a good thing. 
Would not go back.

Absolutely fantastic Chicken Lo Mien!

Since Lo Mien is my favorite, it's what I usually use to gauge how good a Chinese spot is. I've had dishes at other places that have had greasy noodles, or super thin pieces of meat, but Hunan's was absolutely perfect. 

My mother always told me that you can tell how well food is prepared by eating it cold - which I did with the leftovers a few hours later. It was still delicious!  I just had to take the time to leave a good review. 

The overall atmosphere was very casual, which makes it the perfect place to stop in for a last-minute meal. I forgot to take a picture, but I'll get one next time. It's super close to our house, and we will be back for sure.

Four of us went here having read Yelp reviews. We had a spring roll, a cabbage roll, fried dumplings and won ton soup as appetizers. Spring roll and cabbage roll veggies still had texture to them and tasted great, according to persons eating them. I had the dumplings and tried the wonton soup. Dumplings were fried well and filling was really tasty. Wontons in soup really good too. We had the tempura veggies also. They were good, not greasy. Had green peppers in there which I thought was unusual but good. For entree's the ladies had the Hawaiian chicken which was really good. I thought it would be really sweet but it was just right. I had the happy family which was a stir fry with scallops, shrimp, calamari, chicken. All the meats were cooked correctly without being over done. All in all this was a very good dining experience. Service was good. Food seemed to be cooked to order. I will definitely be back!
Personally I loved my dish I'm into the exotic/different culture foods however my dinner buddies wasn't so fond of there's.
Love their noodles a lot

One of my favorite Chinese restaurants hands down. The portions are huge and the food is always properly prepared. The staff is friendly and attentive. It's so good, it usually has a short wait, but it's worth it.

Authentic Taiwanese food outside Pittsburgh? Say no more! 

Just down the street from Trader Joe's, Ting's offers amazing comfort food and doesn't shy away from delights such as kidney and intestines. Love their selection, friendly service and affordable prices. I've only ordered takeout but would be happy to eat in if I could convince colleagues to go out on a limb with me!

Highly recommended the pork belly over rice combo with tea egg. At $6.50, the mesh of minced belly with delicious gravy and the bright pop of pickle makes this the ultimate comfort food at a steal of a price!
Chinese food from this restaurant is really just so so. It is not worth the price to some degree.

I wish I could give no stars!!!! I ordered food from here today for lunch!!!! It was delivered!! I open my General tso chicken and found a bug!! Sorry forgot to take pics! I go up there and show them they say it's part of the sauce!!! Umm no the lady picks it up and says it's a small bug!!! IDC  it's gross!!! I ask for my money and my tip back!!! She asked me for the pop!!!! Are u serious lady!!! Long story short don't order from here!!! Their gross!!

Food is always good here. I eat here every time I'm in town. They usually are able to make traditional Chinese dishes that are not on the menu. My favorites are Szechuan eggplant, beef cho fun (dry), Cantonese style Lobster, chicken pan fried noodles, Peeking ribs, seafood birds nest, Chinese style steamed fish, mapo tofu, and Malay green beans. Best Chinese food on the west side of Cleveland!

My (Chinese) family and I come here a lot and the food is always great and authentic with fast service (like 10-15 minutes for food to come out). I'm not sure exactly what my parents order because they always get traditional Chinese dishes but every time it's been really good, my favorites are the dried pepper chicken (À±×Ó¼¦¶¡) and mapo tofu. Their beef tendon, walnut shrimp (it was a chef special so not sure if it's served every day), and pine nut fried whole fish are also great! Never tried the more Americanized fare and never had an interest in it, their Chinese dishes are great and the portions are good too.
Today was my first time here! It was SO good! I have been looking for a good Chinese place and we definitely found a new favorite!

Very mediocre Taiwanese food. Ordered the Popcorn chicken and flavor was okay but it was difficult to chew, really tough and oily. The beef noodle soup was no better. The noodles were too soft from being boiled too long and the beef had a decent flavor but was way too tough and chewy.

I just got my first takeout order from Ting's and it definitely will not be my last. Hands down they have one of the best egg rolls around and my chicken and broccoli was flavorful and delicious. I can't wait to try more dishes! Totally recommend!
First time ordering from here. The food arrived earlier than expected and it was still piping hot. I thoroughly enjoyed my meal and will be a happily returning customer!

Amazing and authentic food - I'm so glad we happened upon this place.  Here to see the mighty Steelers play against the Chargers and needed to get a quick bite to eat.  EVERYTHING we had was excellent, from the seafood hot and sour soup to the hot pots and Taiwanese small plates.  The wontons in chili oil are a must have but so were the 7 other apps we ate before our meal!!  Service was excellent as well, very friendly, helpful and knowledgeable about the menu.

We were in Westlake and wanted nice place for lunch. Checked Yelp and Aristo was right across the street.  Small and nice atmosphere. Does have a bottle service for bringing your own wine. Nice varied menu with lunch portions. We had the lettuce wraps which we thought were delicious. Freshly made with hoisin on the side. Also has balsamic glazed salmon and General Tao chicken with real fried rice. Was delicious and a huge portions. Couldn't finish it all and took home the chicken and lettuce wraps, where our wonderful waitress added additional friend rice and lettuce leave. That to me is going over the top.

I was really looking forward to trying Ting's and it did not disappoint.  The menu was stacked with lots of great looking options.  I wan wanted to try the pork shank, but I was warned it was a huge portion and I wasn't mega hungry.  I went with the hot and soup as an app and the beef noodle soup as the main course.  The hot and sour soup was different, as all authentic places have there own flavor, yet very good.  The broth of the beef noodle soup was it's highlight, very flavorful.  I plan on coming often.
Hot sour soup is very good as well as the calamari.Our server provided excellent service.

Good food, they're not shady with their portion sizes either. The staff laughs and talks with you and makes sure your order is correct. There is a wait when you order sushi or California rolls. But it's totally worth it. It's always made fresh every day and you can see them cut the avocado, and which I've had bad at other locations but never this one. You can tell they take pride in their food/job. I eat here for lunch maybe 2 times a week and it's always sushi/California roll. It's my go to light lunch.
Didn't think I would find a place around here that serves Taiwanese beef ramen soup! #asiancomfortfood

Solid location.

This place has everything you'd want from a Noodles and Co. The selection is great, they have Truffle Mac :0 and there's lots of space to eat and hang out with your friends! Portion sizes for the food are big, which is great for people who are hungry and those who want some leftovers for later.

I recommend trying some of the heat spice they have next to the drink machines. It's not that spicy but adds a slight heat and smoke flavor to whatever you're having.

Prompt delivery. Decent portions. Kids ordered LoMein and it was made using a skinny noodles, like vermicelli, instead of typical 1/4in LoMein noodles.  I tried a new dish. It was ok but not what I expected from description( that could happen when ordering new items). I ordered from the spicy menu and when prompted to choose from mild , medium, or hot... I chose hot.  I found a few tiny bits of pepper. Tasted very mild. Dish, made with white rice, was ok but curry and spicy flavors were very mild.   Fried( like slightly burnt/over cooked) flavor clung to the rice. 

I may try again after a while. - But in person. 

During My previous visit the server was quiet, but prompt. Food was not as unexpected but lacked the range of flavors and texture of some regional Chinese or Asian menus.

I've had lunch from here a few times and let me say "WOW". Egg rolls are always super crunchy and full of meat. Crab rangoon has a good amount of crab and extra crispy like I like. I have gotten the Szezuan chicken 3 times now. First time asked for spicy and it was great except my tolerance for spice is very high and it was not where I wanted it. Second time extra spicy and it was very good but needed a little more. Today and asked for extra extra spicy and again "WOW". Would not recommend if you can't handle heat but if you can the flavor with the ton of chiles in it is amazing. Oh and they have given me a 5 dollar gift certificate TWICE!
Our go-to restaurant for asian take out in the north hills. Wide selection and consistently very good food. A bit pricey, but the food quality makes up for it.
The food has significantly went downhill from a few years ago  . I ordered the pad Thai a few weeks ago and it was inedible, tasted like it had buffalo sauce on it.

We stopped for dinner before heading to the Clague Theatre as it is very close.   The ambiance is nothing special, but is adequate.   We were seated quickly and provided menus.   Service was a bit slow and 3 of us ordered hot tea, of varying types.   The tea arrived but was barely warm.  The menu is varied, with something for everyone.   I started with the wonton soup and an egg roll.   They were both very good.   The egg roll was served with sides of sweet and sour and hot mustard, which really enhanced the flavor of the egg roll.    My husband and I split the chicken lo mein and the sesame chicken, which also came with fried rice.    Both dishes were large and much more than we could eat, so we had leftovers.   The sauce on both dishes was excellent and the chicken was very tender.   Definitely a dish I would order again.   The rice wasn't anything special.   

Prices were typical of this type restaurant.

Been to this spot many times in the past, and I don't remember it being this bad. Just got takeout, and the lady that took my order just kept yelling "what else", should've known from the start.  Got the gold standard General Tso's chicken. In one word, disappointing. 3 pieces of small breaded chicken and the rest was giant pieces of raw green pepper. They obviously try to make this dish seem large without putting any substance into it. The hot & sour soup was on point, the rest of the meal was about par. 

TL;DR  Better off going somewhere else

Stopped for a late lunch. Service was great, staff was very friendly. Food was very good. We got Shrimp Shumai fried, Zha Jiang noodles and BBQ beef over rice. The beef was my favorite dish. I liked all the photos available in this posting, I don't mind that they were posted by the owner, although I understand the bias there. (Read this in many complaints). I found the photos helpful when ordering as I was completely unfamiliar with this kind of cuisine. Will certainly go back!
The price is generally more expensive than other Chinese restaurants but also more less modified Chinese food.

Worst Chinese food I've ever had. Absolutely tasteless! We got pork egg Foo yung and sesame chicken, both with fried rice. The sauce on the sesame chicken is like water. The gravy on the egg foo yung is the texture of mud and has no taste. Do yourself a favor and go down the street to Mandarin House on Pleasant Valley.
I love the zoodles option and Lucy is amazing. Everytime I come here she is so freindly and thoughtful. Zoodle Truffle Mac is my favorite

Wow.  I was really surprised to find any positive reviews for this place, let alone so many.  This is overall one of the very worst restaurants I have ever been to.  We stopped here on a whim just because we saw it as we drove past and we were hungry.  This experience makes me understand the people who prefer to always eat at chain restaurants so they know what they're getting.

My companion had wanton soup and szechuan chicken; I had hot and sour soup and vegetable chow mein.  Her soup was so bad she didn't eat it; mine was also not good.    Hot and sour soup is one of the things I always get to test out a new Chinese place, and this is one of the worst I've had.  It had a very cloudy appearance, almost like gravy.  Neither of our entrees were good.  Mine was almost exclusively bean sprouts, and had not much flavor at all.  Hers just had a bad taste.  The worst were the sweet and sour sauce and hot mustard they keep on the table.  They were so watery and oddly dark brown.  I didn't want to eat anything on my plate that they touched because it seemed like they must certainly be spoiled.

The service was fine.  The bathrooms looked clean, but smelled awful, like rotten food.

This place is one of the healthier options for lunch in Oakland, and a good alternative to the fast food joints in the area.  As the name suggests, they specialize in noodles, which includes American and Italian-inspired types as well as the Asian-inspired ones you might think of.  I've tried several varieties here and at the downtown location, including the penne rosa, pesto cavatappi, and mac and cheese.  Although the dishes may not be the most exciting ones you'll find in the area, all of them have been served hot, have tasted good, and have been filling, providing for a solid lunch (or dinner, in the case of my downtown excursions).  The small size is perfect for a lunch portion, whereas the larger size is better for dinner, and meat can be added for an upcharge.  I've tried the parmesan chicken (on the pesto cavatappi) and the BBQ pork (on the macaroni), and both have been tasty and have gone well with these dishes.

Although I don't usually order a drink, as other reviewers have mentioned, they have the Coke freestyle machine, which provides for unlimited flavor customization options. However, there is another establishment down the street that has a Boylan soda fountain, so if I'm feeling like a soda, that's more my speed. 3.5 stars.

Good Authentic Chinese spot. 

I ordered the double-sauteed pork will an egg roll. 

The egg roll had a nice crisp exterior. The cabbage inside was well executed. The filling was adequately porcine-flavored. The sweet and sour dipping sauce brought in a sweetness that balances out this traditional app quite well. 

The pork in my dish was well executed: tender. The side of rice was OK, but not particularly fragrant or lightly toothy as the short grains I prefer. The veggies in the dish were classicly undercooked, which I find offputting. Nevertheless, the dish was tasty and well balanced in sweetness, acidity, and fat.

My family comes here all the time. Service is always the same, fast and friendly. The food always comes out hot!!! Usually get the pepper steak or curry beef and always comes out delicious. The wanton soup is a MUST!

Not sure what has happened to this place... about 3 months ago we were told that they were closing for renovations... I think that was a lie. None of the same staff is there, and the food is not the same AT ALL. 

Ordered take out a couple of weeks ago and said the cook must have had an off night, ordered take out again today and got Over cooked rice, over cooked lo-main... questionable meat. I doubt that we'll be back. 

The new management seems questionable at best. When I asked if Margaret was in, he originally said yes, when I asked if you could go get her, he said she wasn't there. I asked when her next scheduled work day was, and he told me she retired. All in less than 15 minutes. I don't think they want you to know that they are no longer Hunan of Lyndhurst.  But like the new smaller sign says, Hunan China Sea. 

Be Warned!

Very relaxing music and atmosphere.

My dinner of wild salmon with vegetables with light honey glaze was very good.

My wife's chicken with Chinese broccoli was also very good.

Look forward the next visit.

Very cool little place off of McKnight. I am happy that I can finally get my pork belly somewhere closer than Squirrel Hill. It makes me happy to see a place so close to home where they serve more authentic Chinese food dishes (though they also still serve the standard fare one might expect).
Best fried dumplings I've ever had. Not an expert but everything seems made to order and made from scratch.

This place used to be called "China Star".  It is under new ownership but the restaurant has not been renamed on the door yet.  They said it won't happen for another 2 weeks or so.  Till that happens, it is going to be the old name with old menu.  You can either wait 2 weeks for things to settle or just ask for the new menu like I did.  Just don't get confused by the door sign.

I had conflicting reviews from my friends about this place so I decided to check this out myself.  From yelp, I also learned that they do both Taiwanese and Szechuan food.  (just to clarify, Szechuan is the southwestern part of china known for their spicy food, and Taiwan is the eastern-not-so-part-of-china).  

We tried both the Szechuan and Taiwanese dishes.  And I am looking forward to their new Taiwanese menu.  

Boiling beef (Szechuan) - the beef was soft and done right.  But the sauce was nothing but salty and spicy.  it is supposed to be more complex than that.  and to be honest there are better Szechuan restaurants in squirrel hill area. (3/5)

Taiwanese beef noodle: (https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/tings-kitchen-pittsburgh?select=6yQcm5wONjI9M9cCg_o8ZA) one of the best in town. (5/5)

Taiwan chicken nuggets (https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/tings-kitchen-pittsburgh?select=NLq9ud9hNAw-QnFpv7V3aw)  crispy on the outside and soft in the inside.  I think it is thigh meat not breast meat, which would be a plus. but i am not 100% sure. (4/5)

Taiwan pork rice (https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/tings-kitchen-pittsburgh?select=4LUy7n-J7Ca9jZE44QF_hg)  it is really really good. but rather small.  I have heard they do lunch box / set dinner version too, hopefully those will be bigger. (5/5)

Zhangcha duck.  The biggest surprise of the night.  Crispy skin and fat enough duck.  (6/5)

There were few more dishes too. and free dessert (https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/tings-kitchen-pittsburgh?select=k8IU71im9pTAWFiiSEVz8g)

overall, I am looking forward to this place and certainly will be back again.  Just wish them best of luck, as their location is not ideal.  I won't be coming if I do not drive.  hopefully, they will do well in this Uber generation.

final verdict: best Chinese food in Ross township if not north of Allegheny

Hot tea was cool. My wife's soup was cool. All you could taste was heavy oil on both of our main dishes.Egg roll was not an egg roll with shrimp. No hot yellow mustard. Asked for steamed rice and got fried. Asked for Garlic Pork but was brought out chicken. Sent it back. We grew up in N.Y. and spent a lot of weeks traveling China and this is a poor representation of good Chinese food. We tried this in the past and couldn't remember the name. It was the same place we had eaten. Disappointing! It was noon and there was only one person eating?
Nice change from Americanized Chinese food. Beef noodle soup was delicious. Interesting appetizers.

What can I say? When a place makes their egg rolls fresh you got to love it. What a wonderful dinner. I had Sea, Wind and Fire. Delicious. The shrimp was perfectly cooked. They were the big ones. Just enough fire to make this a perfect meal. My girlfriend had chicken fried rice. If you go away hungry you didn't eat it all. The entire meal was fantastic. Highly recommend this place. Go and find out for yourself.

Very authentic Asian flare!

Service: superb! The waitress was very patient since i wanted everything on the menu. 

Food: i love Asian food so I can tell whether it's authentic or not. I got the salt and pepper shrimp and it was so so so tasty!! The shrimp was meaty and I do recommend it if you are craving a seafood dish. The cold appetizer was a mix of tendon and meat. I asked for less spicy but it still came pretty hot. Not bad since it is meant to be spicy. Im just not able to eat too hot. My friend ordered the spicy chicken and the taste was so good, fragrant and simply delicious, but again i couldn't eat too much of it because it was way too hot.
The owner, I presume doesn't smile. When asked for what she would recommend from the menu, i was told everything. The tea served was lukewarm. The food was average

This place is not what u think it is! It is not Italian (which I assumed it was when I saw their new sign up, less than a year ago). Want an all-American burger? They have it. Want a ramen Burger? They have it. Want a veal wiener or pork schnitzel? They have it. Want the usual American style Chinese fare like sweet and sour pork, General Tso's Chicken, orange beef, and fried rice?  They have it. They have 2 menus--the one I cannot read (in Chinese) is the one I ask for--I just have our waitress translate!  This menu has all the authentic, exotic Chinese dishes that I love! Since I discovered this place, I have not found it necessary to go downtown for Chinese food, ever again. It's all here, and it is much cleaner!  Everything I have ever ordered has been fresh & scrumptious...and the price is right (often cheaper than what I have paid downtown). My recommendations: Seafood King and Fish Maw Soup (a large bowl for $15.95) has become my new comfort food...even if it comes only in a large bowl, it heats up perfectly in the microwave for days to come; Saut¨¦ed Flounder & vegetables nested on whole fried bones for $28.00--you get the best of both worlds...feast on the crispy fins and tails while savoring the tasty flounder nuggets! Also good are the Aristo Rib eye Steak (boneless rib eye with Chef's Special Steak Sauce ($22.00). They can cook up your choice of seafood in a variety of ways: ginger & Scallion, black bean sauce, steamed, salt baked, garlic and wine. You have to call ahead if you like to order Peking Duck. This place is just starting to be discovered and sometimes they have a skeleton crew that can't keep up... so if you are in a hurry, it is better to take out, or come during off hours. Don't be dissuaded by the parking lot, which is always full--not everybody is at the restaurant. I promise you--once you've sampled the food here, you will never again be happy with the usual cheap Chinese hole in the wall take out, because you can also order take out here and the food is SO much better! Bon appetit!

A very good place to go for Taiwanese and Szechuan. There are some excellent vegetarian options. 

I ordered the Garlic Eggplant, and it turned out to be a great choice. The garlic and eggplant flavors were subtly balanced. I also tried the mixed vegetable dish, which was also good.

Our service was terrific. After reading on the website that the owner is nicknamed "The Princess," I was lucky enough to meet her and talk about the restaurant. You won't meet a nicer person!

We had a great time here and look forward to going back. Many people order takeout, but I find their dining room very comfortable. 

Although they offer many of the Americanised Chinese dishes, like General Tso, I encourage you to try the many authentic selections.

Rude! (No cookie for you) 
This was my first and last visit, stopped in for a quick lunch. My food was just ok, but an important FYI there are shrimp in the egg rolls which was not made aware to me. After finishing my lunch I was just sitting enjoying my tea, I paid my bill and asked may I have my fortune cookie now? The reply back was "No fortune cookie for lunch!!" The lady was so very rude and I've never had food at a Chinese restaurant where I was not given a fortune cookie to conclude my meal... silly but true!

I am giving 4 stars based on my past experience .. great food & service . but today if it had been the 1st visit it would have been my last based on service alone .. I could tell the waitress was totally not paying attention when I ordered .. I also asked for a chicken dish to be made with shrimp for an up charge which she said was not allowed so I did insist she ask someone since I have done it a zillion times b4 .. she then returned to the table with a dish I did not even order insisting I did .. she got a bit snippy about it so I got a bit snippy back & told her I would know what I ordered & that she never did take my full order .. the lady that I believe is an owner quickly stepped in & took my order thankfully .. I did ask for white vs fried rice (I do not care for theirs for some odd reason) & got fried rice w/my dish (which I was allowed to sub the shrimp for) & just decided to let that one go vs having the rice swapped out since I was on my lunch hour & had wasted 25 minutes already just trying to get my order placed

We stopped in for a quick lunch on a business trip and were so impressed with everything from the decor to the service. The food which is made to order was some of the best Chinese I have had.  I highly recommend the General Tsos Chicken.

This is an ASIAN restaurant, and a very good one!  Portions are large, waitress was super nice, and the food was some of the. best Asian ever!  They have the best crab rangoon in the city!  Go there.  Bring your friends.  This is a new place and deserves to be supported!

Had the fantastic Black Pepper Lamb, it's like a stir fry and is amazing. Probably going to be dreaming about that meal. Also had the Pork Belly Minis - sweet bun 'taco' with pork belly and an amazing pickled veggie slaw. Wow. This place great.

Ting's is tucked away in a shopping center by Ross Park Mall. Although they offer Sichuan and Taiwanese cuisine,I definitely think their Taiwanese food was their strength. 

We ordered the Taiwanese popcorn chicken, pork belly over rice, and a chicken flaming pan. The Taiwanese chicken was definitely my favorite of the three - it was well-flavored and crispy, and I also really liked the crispy basil leaves in there. The pork belly over rice was good and a decent portion for $6, but I have had better elsewhere. I was disappointed by their chicken flaming pan. First, the chicken was a strange pink color (I'm guessing from the spices that they used?) and was barely spicy at all. The waitresses were really sweet and our food came out very quickly as well.

I wouldn't go out of my way to come back here, but it's a good place to stop in for some authentic Taiwanese food if you're out doing some shopping.

They don't give you chopsticks or folks when you get take out. I can't understand how they messed up the scallion pancake, it's really bad. Basically I haven't found anything good from here after dining here multiple times (because it's close to home). Their 4.5 out of 5 stars is totally inflated with reviews from the owners friends maybe ?!

I'm pretty sure today is the last time Im getting food from this place. It used to be pretty good food but the last three times have been a disappointment that I was hoping would change. Tonight I ordered a chicken dish that was supposed to be served with broccoli and a spicy sauce. Instead, I got the same mix of crinkle cut carrots, water chestnuts, onions, and broccoli that is served with every other dish in a bland and not at all spicy sauce. The chicken tasted like it had been cooked the third time right before they gave it to me and was awful. The customer service is nonexistent and the only good thing about this the place is the speed, but that's probably because they only throw together reheated ingredients in one of four combinations anyway. I know this place has a great following, and I used to be in that group, but I'm done. If you want decent food, seek elsewhere.

This place is not what u think it is! It is not Italian (which I assumed it was when I saw their new sign up, less than a year ago). Want an all-American burger? They have it. Want a ramen Burger? They have it. Want a veal wiener or pork schnitzel? They have it. Want the usual American style Chinese fare like sweet and sour pork, General Tso's Chicken, orange beef, and fried rice?  They have it. They have 2 menus--the one I cannot read (in Chinese) is the one I ask for--I just have our waitress translate!  This menu has all the authentic, exotic Chinese dishes that I love! Since I discovered this place, I have not found it necessary to go downtown for Chinese food, ever again. It's all here, and it is much cleaner!  Everything I have ever ordered has been fresh & scrumptious...and the price is right (often cheaper than what I have paid downtown). My recommendations: Seafood King and Fish Maw Soup (a large bowl for $15.95) has become my new comfort food...even if it comes only in a large bowl, it heats up perfectly in the microwave for days to come; Saut¨¦ed Flounder & vegetables nested on whole fried bones for $28.00--you get the best of both worlds...feast on the crispy fins and tails while savoring the tasty flounder nuggets! Also good are the Aristo Rib eye Steak (boneless rib eye with Chef's Special Steak Sauce ($22.00). They can cook up your choice of seafood in a variety of ways: ginger & Scallion, black bean sauce, steamed, salt baked, garlic and wine. You have to call ahead if you like to order Peking Duck. This place is just starting to be discovered and sometimes they have a skeleton crew that can't keep up... so if you are in a hurry, it is better to take out, or come during off hours. Don't be dissuaded by the parking lot, which is always full--not everybody is at the restaurant. I promise you--once you've sampled the food here, you will never again be happy with the usual cheap Chinese hole in take out, because you can also order take out here and the food is SO much better! Bon appetit!

Update: This awesome place just catered my daughter's rehearsal dinner at our church hall--presentation was great, service was stellar, cost was reasonable, and every single one of our guests LOVED the food! Talk to Nancy--she's the best!

I can't even give this a half a star. Service was horrible, food was bland to say the least, and the sauce was not a sauce but a coagulated brown gravy. Two thumbs down in my book! Only gave it 1 star because Yelp wouldn't take my no star review.
This is probably the best Chinese food I've had in a while it was amazing and I'm very picky when it comes to the rice but the rice was good I'll definitely be ordering again
Great food! My daughters eat this all the time!! Fast service, low price..but most important tastes great!! Highly recommended!

I'm sad to have to write this review! I have many fond memories of Wah Fu's growing up and have eaten here many times. I will still come here but narrow my selections down to a few items. My sister found a wooden bristle in her food, the manager said it was from the brush that they use to clean the wok. My Chicken Sub Gum was not so good, the fried rice was flavorless. I ended up with Egg Fu Young and it was decent. The waitress was great and the staff was friendly.

Probably the worse take out I have had since moving to Cleveland. Almost  the entire order was wrong and it should've been a sign when I went back to get it and there was no name on the bag and he asked what I order and he just handed me a bag.General Tso's no breading and flavorless, low mein definitely no lo mein.. egg rolls dry but my wife loved her sweet and sour chicken..
If you like quality and good taste, do not eat here.  Everything was awful!  So sad, this location would've been very convenient to pick up on my way home from work once in a while..

Finally a delicious Asian restaurant, we have been there twice and both times the food was amazing! The waitresses were very helpful explaining the menu because we were new and the menu is extensive. The food is made fresh, a far cry from other Chinese restaurants that pound the chicken till its dry and hard like leather, the sauces from a jar. It's a nice quiet atmosphere with friendly staff and excellent dishes cooked and served fresh. The fortune cookies are not anything special and both times they were stale.....we just read the fortune.

THEIR FOOD LATELY HAS BEEN TERRIBLE! We love orange chicken so that's usually what we order from this place. It used to be awesome, but the past 3 times we've gone it just has not been right; the chicken gets harder and drier each time! Last night we decided to try it again since it's right down the street, only to be disappointed once again. Biting down on a piece of this orange chicken was like biting down on a extra crispy ball of grease saturated fried batter. The chicken had been so severely overcooked it was hardly noticeable when we opened up one of the unappetizing balls of crunchy-ness. Bottom line this place will NEVER get our business again!
P.S. customer service sucks unless a male takes your order which doesn't happen often.

A hidden gem!
What a delicious meal that I had here for lunch.
The name is deceiving, it's a wonderful Chinese/Asian restaurant.
There is plenty of parking.
The restaurant is clean and inviting.
The staff was friendly and welcoming.
The prices are not over priced. Great lunch specials! 
The wonton Soup was fantastic and the General Tso dinner was the best I've ever eaten!
I highly recommend you trying this hidden gem.
It's my new favorite local Asian restaurant !!

Amazing authentic Chinese food right in the suburbs! No need to go to Asiatown because Aristo Bistro (weird name for an Asian restaurant, I know) is serving up the same great food right in Westlake. The chef and owner actually used to own Bo Loong before the new management bought them and he knows how to cook!

This place used to be Little Budapest and I'm guessing the decor was carried over because it definitely doesn't look like a typical Asian restaurant inside. It's bright, clean and cozy, with maybe 8-10 tables plus seating at the small bar.  

Their menu is interesting, with typical Chinese American fare, authentic Cantonese dishes like Peking Duck, steamed whole fish, and Chow Fun, along with some Euro items like calamari, fettuccine Alfredo, schnitzel and spaetzel and American offerings like burgers and lobster rolls.  Their selection of appetizers and soups is huge ranging from garlic wings, assorted kabobs, and lettuce wraps, to udon, ramen, and coconut noodle soups. 

I've been here with my family and fianc¨¦ a few times and the food has been fantastic. Portions are large and service is great.  The young lady that works there most of the time is super nice and patient with you if you have an questions on the menu. Their egg rolls are really good. Nice and crisp and flavorful without being greasy.  I also like the Saucy Chow Fun, pan fried noodles, and stir fried Japanese egg plant ...so good!

They also have a nice selection of hot teas like you'll find in Asia town restaurants and they have a few beers on tap now.

I'll continue to come to Aristo for the great food and service without having to drive downtown! Win! Stop in and check out this hidden gem!

We didn't read through a ton of reviews before going, just made a snap decision based on the 4.5 stars and the first few pictures, which looked delicious. This was not a good decision!

We arrived at 6 on a Saturday to a completely empty restaurant, which we should have taken as a sign. I got Szechuan Beef, which turned out to be bland, overly sweet and not at all spicy. The fried rice was oily, cold and dried out. My wife ordered MaPo Tofu and it was so salty, she chugged all the water on the table trying to rinse her mouth. The kids' lo mein was inoffensive bland basic noodles. 

I noticed another reviewer pointed out that most of the pictures were uploaded by the owner. I wish the food were actually as fantastic as those pictures would lead you to believe.

Hidden Gem! We got the kids chicken tenders as well as two orders of orange chicken. The orange chicken was wonderful and my son demolished the kids chicken tenders. We will definitely be back to try the sp<U+00E4>tzle.

I ate at Wah Fu on a Monday night with a very large group.  The restaurant was able to split the checks, which is always so helpful.  We were seated at one long table which made it nice as well.  I ordered the three-course dinner with pop and cookie.  The pot stickers were ok.  The egg roll came with shrimp in it, which I should've asked about, because I don't like seafood.  The egg drop soup didn't have any flavor and was thicker than I would've liked it to be so I ate very little of it..  My entree, General Tso Chicken, was very good.  The medium spice was just right, and I was pleasantly surprised to receive fried rice instead of white.  I think that if I had just ordered the entree without the starters that I would've given a higher rating.

The name is misleading but it's Chinese fare. The service is very courteous. The portions are huge and the prices are reasonable. They are yet to get a bar license. The veg spring rolls were bland but huge. The stir fried tofu with Mongolian sauce had a nice flavor with a mild kick. The fried rice was hot and tasty.

This is a nice quiet little place.  The menu is odd. They have Thai, Chinese, Japanese, German, etc dishes. Normally I won't even go to a place with that type of menu. I believe the owners are ethnic Chinese- but maybe grew up in SE Asia. 
We ordered a mix.  Chinese - honey walnut shrimp. Very good, the dressing is condensed milk and mayo (?). Good, more southern Chinese. 
The gyoza, Japanese, is good.  The lettuce wraps (SE Asia) were ok, I've had better. 
The service was good. Environment very nice. 
Overall I would come back.

Our family had a Saturday in together, which doesn't happen often, and we decided to order Hunan carryout located in the Greens of Lyndhurst.  AWFUL EXPERIENCE!  Our take order was a total of $19.00.  We ordered appetizers and a dinner.  After we ate our cold and starchy potstickers, my wife and I took one bite of the beef and both realized that it had a sour taste.  I smelled and inspected the meat further and more than one piece had the same order (sour/bad meat).  I contacted the store and advised them of the what we discovered.  The person that answered the phone was not friendly, obviously did not know how to address this sort of issue.  The best answer she came up with was "would you like another order".  I drove up to the store and brought the meal and one of the egg rolls back.  I was not greeted, not once did they apologize, and then they partially refunded our meal.  I addressed it at the counter, and the owner stated that I ate the potstickers and one of the egg rolls (appetizers) so they would not consider a reimbursement.  I explained that her practice was not very customer service oriented.  This comment was met with push back and attitude.  

So, to recap....  I drove there and back twice tonight, ate sour food with the potential of myself and family getting sick, I am still hungry, now angry, and was met with a partial refund on take out.  I WILL NEVER GO TO THIS RESTAURANT AGAIN AND NEITHER SHOULD YOU.
Good, inexpensive food that always tastes fresh. Employees always look happy and are incredibly friendly. Very tasty crab rangoon. Definitely worth it every time!

Horrible.  one star is too much.  We just order food from East China on Broadview. Two bites into my general tsos, I pull out a black hair about 14" long. That kept coming from the depths of the bowl, like it was tossed with the chicken and rice. Wife calls as I am obviously done with that nonsense, they place her on hold. About 7 minutes later, shes still on hold, and in the car on her way there.  The husband admitted it was their fault and apologized, a woman we assuming was his wife since its family operated gave my wife one heck of a time and argument.  Such a nasty woman, human hair is all through the food you served me, how can you not think that is a problem!!  How can you not graciously apologize and make it right?  Any normal person can understand, that is not right and must be immediately and politely rectified. Gave the guy an $8 tip too... Yep, not only lacking in kitchen safety procedures, but also in customer service. After some argument, we received a partial refund.  Do yourself a favor, go else where.  The woman who works there is just not quite right and definitely not concerned about customer satisfaction.

UPDATE:  The husband and owner made a comment of "Its only one hair".  Seriously?  You think as its only one its acceptable.  Deplorable.  You be be ashamed of yourself.

This is a disappointment. I was excited to try this place as there are only a few authentic Taiwanese restaurant in the area. But after trying it out, I don't think this is even close to authentic as the other options in Pittsburgh. I had the wonton in chili oil and the chicken steak over rice. Both of these are the easy, basic but tasty dish from each cuisine(they claim to be Taiwanese and Szechuan cuisine). 
The wonton came out first, but it was super salty and the filling didn't taste fresh. I would say 2 out of 5. Not a good start. After a little bit, the chicken steak was ready. Nice presentation! It came with some boiled pok choy on the side. First impression of this dish was authentic. Soon I found out that the chicken steak was weird, thickness wise. I've never had chicken steak in my life that was like this. I'm not saying it has to be like a prefect steak. But this is way off. Some parts were half inch thick, which turned out to be the best part, they were juicy but there were only 2-3 pieces like that. Then there are some ones were like paper thin which of course it would be over fried and too dry. So I think the chef defiantly need make some changes on this. 

The taste were alright, the chicken itself doesn't have any flavor, it is solely rely on the seasoning powder, but the powder only covers the top chicken. So, I had some plain fried chicken. At least it came with pork gravy over rice, that was pretty good. 

So,  overall, It didn't live up my expectation. Lot of room to grow. I wouldn't recommend to anyone who is interested in authentic Taiwanese or Szechuan experience.
